expected to bring torrential, flooding rainfall on Tuesday, spreading over large portions of southern Georgia.\n\nThe storm has crossed into Georgia and is expected to move slowly through the southeastern part of the state until its center emerges over the Atlantic around mid-afternoon Tuesday.\n\nDebby could slow down to walking speed by Tuesday night and stall just off the coast of South Carolina through at least Thursday morning. Torrential rainfall could pound parts of Geo"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Georgia (U.S. state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 74}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 89}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 295}, "sentiment": -0.1686274509803921, "breakingScore": 0.6415400329440766}
{"uri": "8261734803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:53:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:53:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:53:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/losangeles/news/tropical-storm-debby-drenching-parts-southeast-up-to-30-inches-rain/", "title": "Slow moving Tropical Storm Debby could bring \"catastrophic flooding\" to parts of Georgia and the Carolinas, forecasters say", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm killed at least five people Monday, four in Florida -- including two children -- and one in Georgia.\n\nAs of 5 a.m. EDT Tuesday, Debby's center was some 50 miles southwest of Savannah, Georgia and 130 miles southwest of Charleston, South Carolina and was moving northeast at 7 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nCBS News senior weather and climate producer David Parkinson says Debby, which has already \"slowed to a near crawl,\" will slow even more as the day goes on.\n\n\"Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday,\" the Miami-based center said. \"From northern North Carolina through portions of the Mid-Atlantic States, 4 to 8 inches of rainfall, with local amounts to 12 inches, are expected through Sunday morning. This rainfall will likely result in areas of considerable flash and urban flooding, with river flooding possible.\"\n\n\"On the forecast track,\" forecasters continued, \"the center of Debby is expected to move offshore the coast of Georgia later today, drift offshore through early Thursday, and then move inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\"\n\nTropical storm-force winds extended outward up to 205 miles east of the center, the center added.\n\nParkinson said at 6 a.m EDT that, \"Much of the low country of South Carolina has already received around a foot of rain. Some bands over the state now are bringing rain at a rate of 2-3 inches per hour. In Savannah, they're beginning to get on the back side of the storm, so the worst rain is over, but another 3 inches or so is possible. In Charleston, however, they're in the thick of it right now, and will see torrential rain off and on for at least the next 36 hours. That area is the best candidate for a total above 2 feet by the conclusion of the storm. There is still another 12-16 inches coming to many areas from Debby.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It weakened to a tropical storm and was moving slowly, bringing drenching rain and severe flooding to many areas.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nRoughly 154,000 customers had no power early Tuesday in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nSouth Carolina Emergency Management Division Director Kim Stenson warned that, \"The heavy rains and flooding currently predicted this week are historic in scope and scale. Our experts with the National Hurricane Center believe flooding to be catastrophic for many parts of South Carolina. Take no chances with this storm.\"\n\nOvernight, a suspected tornado hit Monck's Corner, South Carolina. Mayor Thomas Hamilton said there were no major injuries reported but some buildings and vehicles were damaged.\n\nHe offered photos of some of the damage:\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie.\n\nPresident Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he's asked Mr. Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to his state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order he signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792521", "eventUri": "eng-9792521", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.08235294117647063, "wgt": 207, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8260874403", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:53:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:53:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:48:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/national/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods-threat-of-record-rain-in-georgia-and-the/article_77e5693e-537f-11ef-ace8-5b8e41178084.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths as it turned menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was expected to cause flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. The potential for high water threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina. Up to 18 inches (46 centimeters) was forecast in central and north Florida.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because the storm is moving into Georgia, it doesn't mean the state won't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 linemen were working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to stay off the roads until conditions are safe.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com. One out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was canceled Monday. Nearly 30% of flights scheduled to depart Tampa International Airport were canceled.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden has approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nDebby made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. It's not far from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall less than a year ago as a Category 3 storm.\n\nSue Chewning lives in Steinhatchee and weathered both storms. In her nearly 73 years of living in the area, she said she doesn't recall any direct hits from a hurricane -- until this one-two punch from Idalia and Debby.\n\n\"Some people may say, 'I can't take this anymore'. But I think for the most part ... it's a close-knit community and most of the local people, they're going to stay, dig down, help each other,\" Chewning said.", "source": {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792521", "eventUri": "eng-9792521", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.207843137254902, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-444954840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:12:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:12:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods-threat-of-record-rain-in-georgia-and-the-carolinas-1.6989303", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with catastrophic flooding and was blamed for at least four deaths, with Georgia and South Carolina next in line as the system rips across the southeastern United States.\n\nRecord-setting rain was forecast to cause flash flooding in coastal Georgia and South Carolina, and into North Carolina, with up to 30 inches (76 centimetres) of rainfall in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. Debby made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over the gulf coast of Florida.\n\nThe tropical storm was moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor-trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 metres) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home located southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis said some 17,000 linemen are working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to sit tight until conditions are safe.\n\n\"When the water rises, when you have streets that can be flooded, that's hazardous,\" DeSantis said. \"Don't try to drive through this. We don't want to see traffic fatalities adding up.\"\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been cancelled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com. One out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was cancelled Monday. Nearly 30 per cent of flights scheduled to depart Tampa International Airport were cancelled.\n\nSarasota, Fla., a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nThe storm made landfall early Monday morning near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents.\n\nTaylor County, where Steinhatchee is located, closed several roads due to flooding, Sheriff Wayne Padgett said. Trees and power lines had also fallen across some roads. Padgett advised anyone who had evacuated from low-lying or coastal areas to wait before returning to their homes because the tide had not come in, and it was unclear how deep floodwaters might get later.\n\nLooking out over the Steinhatchee River from the condo above the marina he operates, Chris Williams said he was feeling blessed that the damage wasn't worse. Williams said his power went out at about 5:30 a.m. Monday as the storm was washing ashore, jamming the dock-studded riverfront with tree debris and barrels.\n\nThe small community is roughly 20 miles (32 kilometres) from where Hurricane Idalia crashed ashore less than a year ago.\n\n\"Two in less than a year is pretty bad,\" Williams said. \"You do everything you can possibly do to prepare. And when you've done that, clean up and put it back together and move forward.\"\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nOn Monday, local leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than US$1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nIn Savannah, Jim Froncak piled sandbags into his pickup truck on Monday, as rain was already falling. He said a recent thunderstorm caused so much flooding that he and a friend were able to kayak down a street.\n\n\"That was just a thunderstorm,\" he said. \"So, who knows what could happen with this?\"\n\n------\n\nThis story has been updated to correct that the Big Bend area is north of Tampa, not south of Tampa.\n\n------", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV 98}], "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/8/5/hurricane-debby-1-6989343-1722863370146.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792521", "eventUri": "eng-9792521", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 205, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8260962546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:44:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:44:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:44:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/news/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods/article_ab7873d2-537e-11ef-bedd-9b276c519f88.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods", "body": "Tybee Island Department of Public Works employee Bruce Saunders uses a backhoe to pile sand as a barriers against storm surge from Tropical Storm Debby at a beach access point, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, in Tybee Island, Ga.\n\nHORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths as it turned menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was expected to cause flash flooding, with up to 30 inches possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. The potential for high water threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina. Up to 18 inches was forecast in central and north Florida.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because the storm is moving into Georgia, it doesn't mean the state won't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor-trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 linemen were working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to stay off the roads until conditions are safe.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah, Georgia, said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding. Officials announced a curfew for the city starting at 11 p.m. as some of the heaviest rain is expected to fall overnight.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden has approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nDebby made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. It's not far from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall less than a year ago as a Category 3 storm.\n\nSue Chewning lives in Steinhatchee and weathered both storms. In her nearly 73 years of living in the area, she said she doesn't recall any direct hits from a hurricane -- until this one-two punch from Idalia and Debby.\n\n\"Some people may say, 'I can't take this anymore'. But I think for the most part ... it's a close-knit community and most of the local people, they're going to stay, dig down, help each other,\" Chewning said.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", {"uri": "8261309804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "07:22:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T07:22:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T07:21:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tropical-storm-debby-drenching-parts-southeast-up-to-30-inches-rain/", "title": "Slow moving Tropical Storm Debby could bring \"catastrophic flooding\" to parts of Georgia, South Carolina, forecasters say", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm killed at least five people Monday, four in Florida -- including two children -- and one in Georgia.\n\n\"Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 30 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of eastern Georgia, the coastal plain of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Wednesday,\" the National Hurricane Center said. \"Across portions of central and northeast North Carolina, 6 to 12 inches of rainfall, with local amounts to 18 inches, are expected through Saturday morning. This rainfall will likely result in areas of considerable flash and urban flooding, with significant river flooding expected.\"\n\n\"On the forecast track,\" forecasters continued, \"the center will move across southeastern Georgia this morning, and then off the Georgia coast later today and on Wednesday, and approach the South Carolina coast on Thursday. Some slight weakening is possible today. Some re-strengthening is possible on Wednesday and Thursday when Debby is off the southeastern U.S. coast.\"\n\nTropical storm-force winds extended outward up to 200 miles east of the center, the Miami-based hurricane center said.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It weakened to a tropical storm and was moving slowly, bringing drenching rain and severe flooding to many areas\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nRoughly 161,000 customers had no power early Tuesday in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie.\n\nPresident Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he's asked Mr. Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to his state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order he signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flood", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/08/06/5d28f38e-c2e5-436c-a2fa-d4211cb22abb/thumbnail/1200x630/1d8a4985e0a4b685ca5dcc01fd534e96/tropical-storm-debby-early-080624.jpg?v=33116e4d892fab6878b5c06299369826", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792521", "eventUri": "eng-9792521", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 203, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-445184528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "03:42:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T03:42:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:11:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-ffloods-threat-of-record-rain-in-georgia-and-the-carolinas/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby Hits Florida with Floods, Threat of Record Rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida on Monday with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths in the state and causing flooding before turning menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was expected to cause flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. Up to 18 inches (46 centimeters) was forecast in central and north Florida. A flash flood emergency was issued into Monday evening for the Lake City area, where up to a foot (30.5 centimeters) of rain had fallen and more was expected.\n\nThe potential for high water also threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because the storm was moving into Georgia, it didn't mean the state wouldn't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It since has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least five deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nNearly 200,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 workers were restoring electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to stay off the roads until conditions are safe.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah, Georgia, said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding. Officials announced a curfew for the city starting at 11 p.m. as some of the heaviest rain is expected to fall overnight.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nDebby made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. It's not far from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall less than a year ago as a Category 3 storm.\n\nSue Chewning lives in Steinhatchee and weathered both storms. In her nearly 73 years of living in the area, she said she doesn't recall any direct hits from a hurricane -- until this one-two punch from Idalia and Debby.\n\n\"Some people may say, 'I can't take this anymore'. But I think for the most part ... it's a close-knit community and most of the local people, they're going to stay, dig down, help each other,\" Chewning said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8261646763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:59:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:59:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:58:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/newyork/news/tropical-storm-debby-drenching-parts-southeast-up-to-30-inches-rain/", "title": "Slow moving Tropical Storm Debby could bring \"catastrophic flooding\" to parts of Georgia and the Carolinas, forecasters say", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm killed at least five people Monday, four in Florida -- including two children -- and one in Georgia.\n\nAs of 5 a.m. EDT Tuesday, Debby's center was some 50 miles southwest of Savannah, Georgia and 130 miles southwest of Charleston, South Carolina and was moving northeast at 7 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\n\"Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday,\" the Miami-based center said. \"From northern North Carolina through portions of the Mid-Atlantic States, 4 to 8 inches of rainfall, with local amounts to 12 inches, are expected through Sunday morning. This rainfall will likely result in areas of considerable flash and urban flooding, with river flooding possible.\"\n\n\"On the forecast track,\" forecasters continued, \"the center of Debby is expected to move offshore the coast of Georgia later today, drift offshore through early Thursday, and then move inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\"\n\nTropical storm-force winds extended outward up to 205 miles east of the center, the center added.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It weakened to a tropical storm and was moving slowly, bringing drenching rain and severe flooding to many areas.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nRoughly 154,000 customers had no power early Tuesday in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nSouth Carolina Emergency Management Division Director Kim Stenson warned that, \"The heavy rains and flooding currently predicted this week are historic in scope and scale. Our experts with the National Hurricane Center believe flooding to be catastrophic for many parts of South Carolina. Take no chances with this storm.\"\n\nOvernight, a suspected tornado hit Monck's Corner, South Carolina. Mayor Thomas Hamilton said there were no major injuries reported but some buildings and vehicles were damaged.\n\nHe offered photos of some of the damage:\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie.\n\nPresident Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he's asked Mr. Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to his state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order he signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792521", "eventUri": "eng-9792521", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.08235294117647063, "wgt": 202, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8260844602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:07:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:07:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:06:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://gorgenewscenter.com/2024/08/05/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods-threat-of-record-rain-in-georgia-and-the-carolinas/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths as it turned menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was expected to cause flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. The potential for high water threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina. Up to 18 inches (46 centimeters) was forecast in central and north Florida.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because the storm is moving into Georgia, it doesn't mean the state won't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 linemen were working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to stay off the roads until conditions are safe.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah, Georgia, said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding. Officials announced a curfew for the city starting at 11 p.m. as some of the heaviest rain is expected to fall overnight.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden has approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nDebby made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. It's not far from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall less than a year ago as a Category 3 storm.\n\nSue Chewning lives in Steinhatchee and weathered both storms. In her nearly 73 years of living in the area, she said she doesn't recall any direct hits from a hurricane -- until this one-two punch from Idalia and Debby.\n\n\"Some people may say, 'I can't take this anymore'. But I think for the most part ... it's a close-knit community and most of the local people, they're going to stay, dig down, help each other,\" Chewning said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-445015851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:50:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:50:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:58:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/news/nation-world/hurricane-debby-florida-brings-heavy-rain/507-83599f4f-d99a-49f9-9f98-bf360a551e88", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "More than 300,000 customers were without power in Florida and Georgia.\n\nTAMPA, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths as it turned menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was expected to cause flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. The potential for high water threatened the historic cities of Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina. Up to 18 inches (46 centimeters) was forecast in central and north Florida.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because the storm is moving into Georgia, it doesn't mean the state won't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 linemen were working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to stay off the roads until conditions are safe.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com. One out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was canceled Monday. Nearly 30% of flights scheduled to depart Tampa International Airport were canceled.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nThe storm made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents.\n\nTaylor County, where Steinhatchee is located, closed several roads due to flooding, Sheriff Wayne Padgett said. Trees and power lines had also fallen across some roads. Padgett advised anyone who had evacuated from low-lying or coastal areas to wait before returning to their homes because the tide had not come in, and it was unclear how deep floodwaters might get later.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nIn Savannah, Jim Froncak piled sandbags into his pickup truck on Monday, as rain was already falling. He said a recent thunderstorm caused so much flooding that he and a friend were able to kayak down a street.\n\n\"That was just a thunderstorm,\" he said. \"So, who knows what could happen with this?\"", "source": {"uri": "fox61.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "fox61.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flood", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "2024-08-444912869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:11:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:11:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T18:41:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods-threat-of-record-rain-in-georgia-and-the/article_5d9b71d6-e827-5855-baee-d2046f3cd869.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with catastrophic flooding and was blamed for at least four deaths, with Georgia and South Carolina next in line as the system rips across the southeastern United States.\n\nRecord-setting rain was forecast to cause flash flooding in coastal Georgia and South Carolina, and into North Carolina, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) of rainfall in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said. Debby had made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over the gulf coast of Florida.\n\nThe tropical storm was moving slowly across the northern part of the state, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home located southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nMore than 350,000 customers were without power in Florida and Georgia, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis said some 17,000 linemen are working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to sit tight until conditions are safe.\n\n\"When the water rises, when you have streets that can be flooded, that's hazardous,\" DeSantis said. \"Don't try to drive through this. We don't want to see traffic fatalities adding up.\"\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide; many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com. One out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was canceled Monday. Nearly 30% of flights scheduled to depart Tampa International Airport were canceled.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nThe storm made landfall early Monday morning near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents.\n\nLooking out over the Steinhatchee River from the condo above the marina he operates, Chris Williams said he was feeling blessed that the damage wasn't worse. Williams said his power went out at about 5:30 a.m. Monday as the storm was washing ashore, jamming the dock-studded riverfront with tree debris and barrels.\n\nThe small community is roughly 20 miles (32 kilometers) from where Hurricane Idalia crashed ashore less than a year ago.\n\n\"Two in less than a year is pretty bad,\" Williams said. \"You do everything you can possibly do to prepare. And when you've done that, clean up and put it back together and move forward.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden approved an emergency declaration for Florida on Saturday, and federal emergency staff have been deployed to Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby. Harris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nOn Monday, local leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nIn Savannah, Jim Froncak piled sandbags into his pickup truck on Monday, as rain was already falling. He said a recent thunderstorm caused so much flooding that he and a friend were able to kayak down a street.\n\n\"That was just a thunderstorm,\" he said. \"So, who knows what could happen with this?\"\n\nThis story has been updated to correct that the Big Bend area is north of Tampa, not south of Tampa.\n\nMartin reported from Atlanta. AP journalists Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida; Michael Schneider in Orlando, Florida; Russ Bynum in Savannah, Georgia; Jeffrey Collins in Columbia, South Carolina; and Darlene Superville and Will Weissert in Washington, contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nReformed Gangster Disciples Boss, Harold 'Noonie G' Ward Hosts Citywide Voter Registration Drive During the DNC in Support of VP Kamala Harris\n\nThe UN Acknowledges Foundation for a Drug-Free World With Consultative Status\n\nMCT Reports a 6% Mortgage Lock Volume Decrease in Latest Report", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-444588269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:19:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:19:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:02:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://eu.savannahnow.com/story/weather/severe/2024/08/05/rain-from-debby-to-move-into-savannah-area-monday-followed-by-wind/74671154007/", "title": "Heavy rain from Debby expected to begin in Savannah area Monday; 10-20 inches possible", "body": "Heavy rain is expected to begin in the Savannah area as early as Monday morning with tropical-force winds of 40 mph or more likely moving into the area sometime Monday night, forecasters warned Monday.\n\nThe National Weather Service continues to predict possible rain totals of 10-20 inches in areas of coastal Georgia and the South Carolina Lowcountry and as much as 30 inches in some areas as what is now Hurricane Debby moves slowly through the region.\n\n\"Potentially historic rainfall will likely bring areas of catastrophic flooding mid-to-late week,\" the NWS Charleston office said early Monday.\n\n'It scares me': Savannah Mayor Van Johnson, CEMA address public ahead of Tropical Storm Debby\n\nHeavy rain is expected in the Savannah area through Thursday as Debby loses speed after moving over Florida and into Georgia.\n\nStorm surge levels of 2 to 4 inches are possible. That, along with multiple high-tide cycles as heavy rain falls over several days, could exacerbate inland flooding because the water has nowhere to drain.\n\nBeach erosion also is likely in some areas.\n\nAs of early Monday, the Savannah area is under tropical storm and storm surge warnings, and flood and tornado watches.\n\nAs much as 7 inches of rain is possible in some areas by Tuesday {"uri": "2024-08-445645331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:46:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:46:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T06:59:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/aug/6/slow-moving-tropical-storm-debby-brings-torrential/", "title": "Slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains, major flood threat to southeastern U.S.", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm that killed at least five people on Monday was causing flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe storm's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph) and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\n\"Hunker down,\" Van Johnson, the mayor of Savannah, Georgia, told residents in a social media livestream Monday night. \"Expect that it will be a rough day\" on Tuesday, he said.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nThe National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings well into Monday night for parts of the state including in the island town of Hilton Head.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, drenching and bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of eastern Georgia, the coastal plain of South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Wednesday.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nMore than 140,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Tuesday morning, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp. Nearly 12,000 more were without power in South Carolina early Tuesday.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday and more than 550 flights were canceled early Tuesday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flood", "type":
