{"uri": "8260689201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:14:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:14:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:13:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/tropical-storm-debby-hits-florida-with-floods-and-threat-of-record-rain-1658261.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods and threat of record rain | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby hit Florida with catastrophic flooding and was blamed for at least four deaths, with Georgia and South Carolina next in line as the system rips across the south-eastern United States.\n\nRecord-setting rain was forecast to cause flash flooding in coastal Georgia and South Carolina, and into North Carolina, with up to 30 inches of rainfall in some areas, the National Hurricane Centre said.\n\nDebby made landfall early on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over the gulf coast of Florida.\n\nThe tropical storm was moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nA lorry driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below.\n\nSheriff's office divers found the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida highway patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died on Monday after a tree fell on a mobile home, according to the Levy County sheriff's office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads on Sunday. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger had serious injuries.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nFlorida governor Ron DeSantis said some 17,000 people were working to restore electricity. He told residents to sit tight until conditions are safe.\n\n\"When the water rises, when you have streets that can be flooded, that's hazardous,\" Mr DeSantis said. \"Don't try to drive through this. We don't want to see traffic fatalities adding up.\"\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been cancelled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nOne out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was cancelled on Monday. Nearly 30% of flights scheduled to leave Tampa International Airport were cancelled.\n\nSarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, was one of the hardest hit by flooding.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" said Sarasota County fire chief David Rathbun in a social media update.\n\nThe storm made landfall early Monday near Steinhatchee, Taylor County, a tiny community in northern Florida of fewer than 1,000 residents.\n\nSeveral roads were closed because of flooding, sheriff Wayne Padgett said. Trees and power lines had also fallen across some roads.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County interim emergency director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing on Monday.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine {"uri": "8261879384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:24:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:24:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:23:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/slow-moving-tropical-storm-debby-bringing-torrential-rains-and-flooding-to-southeastern-us/article_3b937815-3f28-50df-83e2-7949680fecfc.html", "title": "Slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains and flooding to southeastern US", "body": "SAVANNAH, Ga. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby has moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities, bringing prolonged downpours and flooding Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm that killed at least five people in Florida and Georgia was causing flash flooding, with up to 25 inches (64 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said in its latest advisory Tuesday morning.\n\n\"Hunker down,\" Van Johnson, the mayor of Savannah, Georgia, told residents in a social media livestream Monday night. \"Expect that it will be a rough day\" on Tuesday, he said.\n\nThe storm's center was just southwest of Savannah early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph) and it was moving northeast at less than 6 mph (10 kph).\n\n\"Tropical cyclones always produce heavy rain, but normally as they're moving, you know, it doesn't accumulate that much in one place,\" Richard Pasch of the National Hurricane Center said Tuesday morning. \"But when they move very slowly, that's the worst situation.\"\n\nTropical cyclones derive their energy from warm water, so Debby has weakened over land, but part of the circulation was interacting with water over the Atlantic, Pasch said. The storm's center is expected to move out over the water off the Georgia and South Carolina coast, then move back inland, so it could restrengthen Wednesday before it moves inland Thursday over South Carolina, he said.\n\nMore than 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain had fallen through Monday at Savannah's airport, and showed no signs of stopping Tuesday, the National Weather Service reported. That's already a month's worth of rain in a single day: In all of August 2023, the city got 5.56 inches (14.1 centimeters) of rain.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced overnight curfews as the rains picked up. Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nCharleston authorities said police were barricading all eight roads leading into the 350-year-old city built on a marshy peninsula, letting only essential workers and emergency personnel in and urging all non-residents to leave Monday night.\n\n\"We need people to make their way out. This is not something you can stay at the bar until 10:45. We need you to take this seriously,\" Charleston Mayor William Cogswell said.\n\nCharleston also opened parking garages so residents could park their cars above floodwaters and updated an online mapping system to show which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nA tornado touched down in Edisto Beach, South Carolina, Monday night, damaging homes and blowing down trees and power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported there officials said.\n\nThe weather service continued issuing tornado warnings well into Monday night for parts of the state including Hilton Head Island.\n\nAt the edge of Hilton Head Island, musician Nick Poulin wasn't overly concerned about Debby since his equipment was inside and he made sure that his car wasn't parked under trees so it won't be hit by falling branches.\n\n\"I'm born and raised here, so we've had plenty of storms,\" he said. \"It's usually not as bad as people hype it up to be.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. Weakening winds made it a tropical storm again, but its slow forward movement and the the ocean water it picked up caused catastrophic in places. About 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department announced. Just north of Sarasota, Manatee County officials said 186 people were rescued.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nGov. Ron DeSantis warned that Florida's threat is far from over as waterways north of the state line fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" DeSantis said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a tractor trailer driver who lost control on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area, flipping over a concrete wall and dangling over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the body of the 64-year-old man from Mississippi in the cab, 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, and in Dixie County, near where Debby made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads. In south Georgia, a 19-year-old man died when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nMore than 140,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Tuesday morning, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp. Nearly 12,000 more were without power in South Carolina early Tuesday.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday and more than 550 flights were canceled early Tuesday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nCollins reported from Columbia, South Carolina. Associated Press contributors include Jeff Martin in Atlanta, Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida; Kate Payne in Tallahassee, Florida; Michael Schneider in Orlando, Florida; Darlene Superville and Will Weissert in Washington, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261583491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:18:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:18:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:18:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/06/world/tropical-storm-debby-bringing-torrential-rains-major-flood-threat-to-southeastern-us/1962208", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains, major flood threat to southeastern US", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Florida -- Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm that killed at least five people on Monday was causing flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\n\"Hunker down,\" Van Johnson, the mayor of Savannah, Georgia, told residents in a social media livestream Monday night. \"Expect that it will be a rough day\" on Tuesday, he said.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings well into Monday night for parts of the state including in the island town of Hilton Head.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, drenching and bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of eastern Georgia, the coastal plain of South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Wednesday.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA man walks through storm surge on the flooded road into Horseshoe Beach, Fla., Monday morning, Aug. 5, 2024. AP PHOTO\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nNearly 160,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday night, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in {"uri": "2024-08-445635093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:37:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:37:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:09:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.aol.com/tropical-storm-debby-expected-send-040936582.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall\n\nALEXA ST. JOHN\n\nAugust 6, 2024 at 12:07 PM\n\nNorthern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nHow much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit. Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina. Russ Bynum contributed from Savannah, Georgia.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X, formerly Twitter, @alexa_stjohn. {"uri": "8261829852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:54:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:54:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T12:52:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/news/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast/", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast - Breitbart", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds\n\nThe Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US SoutheastBy The Associated PressThe Associated Press\n\nTropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby still getting energy from ocean water, expert says\n\nDebby has weakened over land because tropical cyclones derive their energy from warm water, but part of the circulation was still interacting Tuesday with water over the Atlantic, said Richard Pasch, a senior hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe storm's center is expected to move out over the water off the Georgia and South Carolina coast, then move back inland, so it could restrengthen, but it's not clear how much, he said.\n\nTropical storm warnings were posted from northeastern Florida up into North Carolina, and very heavy rain is expected, leading to catastrophic flooding across parts of southeastern Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina and southeastern North Carolina through Friday, he said.\n\n\"Tropical cyclones always produce heavy rain, but normally as they're moving, you know, it doesn't accumulate that much in one place,\" he said. \"But when they move very slowly, that's the worst situation.\"\n\nCharleston ready with sandbags, parking garages\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261766667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:14:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:14:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T12:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/nation/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast/article_d6d90b67-5252-590c-b46a-a0837ffda796.html", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast", "body": "Savannah resident Roi Roizaken loads sandbags into his van as rain from Hurricane Debby starts to fall, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, in Savannah, Ga. Forecasters warned heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.\n\nTropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby still getting energy from ocean water, expert says\n\nDebby has weakened over land because tropical cyclones derive their energy from warm water, but part of the circulation was still interacting Tuesday with water over the Atlantic, said Richard Pasch, a senior hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe storm's center is expected to move out over the water off the Georgia and South Carolina coast, then move back inland, so it could restrengthen, but it's not clear how much, he said.\n\nTropical storm warnings were posted from northeastern Florida up into North Carolina, and very heavy rain is expected, leading to catastrophic flooding across parts of southeastern Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina and southeastern North Carolina through Friday, he said.\n\n\"Tropical cyclones always produce heavy rain, but normally as they're moving, you know, it doesn't accumulate that much in one place,\" he said. \"But when they move very slowly, that's the worst situation.\"\n\nCharleston ready with sandbags, parking garages\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-445581197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:50:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:50:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://cbs6albany.com/news/nation-world/tropical-storm-debby-expected-to-send-flooding-to-the-southeast", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby expected to send flooding to the Southeast", "body": "Northern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nHow much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "cbs6albany.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8261557683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:03:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:03:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.wishtv.com/weather/weather-stories/tropical-storm-debby-is-expected-to-cause-major-flooding-in-the-southeast-heres-how-much-rain-could-fall/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to cause major flooding in the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "(AP) -- Northern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit. Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina. Russ Bynum contributed from Savannah, Georgia.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter.", "source": {"uri": "wishtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WISH-TV | gossip, photos and video", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby drenched Florida on Monday, killing at least four people and threatening southeastern US states with torrential rain and flooding.\n\nA 13-year-old kid died after a tree was thrown onto a mobile home in Levy County, according to the sheriff's office, just after Debby made landfall as a Category One hurricane on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier Monday.\n\nA truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler crashed into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old lady and 12-year-old boy perished in a car accident in Dixie County.\n\nThe storm entered Georgia overnight and is anticipated to move offshore before striking the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power.\n\n\"Please, be very cautious when you're going out,\" he said, adding that Debby's winds had not been as damaging as previous hurricanes that have hit Florida.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has approved emergency declarations for Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, allowing for federal assistance in coordinating disaster relief efforts.\n\nDeSantis also activated his state's National Guard, with more than 3,000 service members mobilized to help with storm response.\n\nEvacuation orders\n\nAs the storm raced into Georgia on Monday evening, the National Hurricane Center reported maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 kph).\n\nStorm surge warnings, which indicate a life-threatening inundation from rising water, are in place in regions of Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina.\n\nDebby was projected to drop \"potentially historic rainfall\" of up to 30 inches as it traveled north, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nHowever, it stated that the storm was weakening after making landfall earlier with sustained winds of 80 mph (130 kph) as a Category One hurricane, the lowest on a scale of five.\n\nMandatory evacuations were ordered for a portion of Citrus County, Florida, with many additional counties under voluntary evacuation orders, according to local media.\n\nBefore Debby arrived, the governors of Georgia and South Carolina proclaimed a state of emergency.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic contender in the US election, postponed events in North Carolina and Georgia this week due to the hurricane, according to local media sources citing her campaign team.\n\nMeanwhile, the US Border Patrol reported that Debby had washed ashore 25 bags of cocaine worth around $1 million off the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were captured.\n\nIn July, at least 18 people were murdered when Hurricane Beryl ripped through the Caribbean before hitting the southern US states of Texas and Louisiana.\n\nScientists {"uri": "2024-08-445175623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "03:26:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T03:26:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:17:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/aug/5/tropical-storm-debby-slams-florida-with-floods-thr/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby slams Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the Carolinas", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida on Monday with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths in the state and the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes before turning menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatening to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was causing flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. It was one of the cities hardest hit by flooding on Monday.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, public safety director for Manatee County. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nA flash flood emergency was issued into Monday evening for the Lake City area in the north central part of the state, where up to a foot (30.5 centimeters) of rain had fallen and more was expected.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said during an afternoon briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It since has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least five deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nNearly 200,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nThe potential for high water also threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding. Officials announced a curfew for the city starting at 11 p.m. as some of the heaviest rain is expected to fall overnight.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said. Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah, Georgia.\n\nDebby made landfall near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. It's not far from where Hurricane Idalia made landfall less than a year ago as a Category 3 storm.\n\nSue Chewning lives in nearby Cross City and has weathered both storms. In her nearly 73 years of living in the area, she said she doesn't recall any direct hits from a hurricane - until this one-two punch from Idalia and Debby.\n\n\"Some people may say, 'I can't take this anymore'. But I think for the most part ... it's a close-knit community and most of the local people, they're going to stay, dig down, help each other,\" Chewning said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-445686728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:22:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:22:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:57:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.ksn.com/weather/weather-stories/ap-the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby still getting energy from ocean water, expert says\n\nDebby has weakened over land because tropical cyclones derive their energy from warm water, but part of the circulation was still interacting Tuesday with water over the Atlantic, said Richard Pasch, a senior hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe storm's center is expected to move out over the water off the Georgia and South Carolina coast, then move back inland, so it could restrengthen, but it's not clear how much, he said.\n\nTropical storm warnings were posted from northeastern Florida up into North Carolina, and very heavy rain is expected, leading to catastrophic flooding across parts of southeastern Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina and southeastern North Carolina through Friday, he said.\n\n\"Tropical cyclones always produce heavy rain, but normally as they're moving, you know, it doesn't accumulate that much in one place,\" he said. \"But when they move very slowly, that's the worst situation.\"\n\nCharleston ready with sandbags, parking garages\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. {"uri": "8261085726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:18:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:18:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:12:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tropical-storm-debby-expected-send-040936220.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "Guests at the Magic Kingdom at Walt Disney World brave wind and rain as bands of weather from Hurricane Debby pass through Central Florida, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, in Bay Lake, Fla. (Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel via AP)ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nNorthern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nHow much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit. Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina. {"uri": "8261783882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:23:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:23:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T12:23:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/national/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast/article_cc88aa70-1b08-5fba-96e9-d1b0ac00354c.html", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds\n\nTropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby still getting energy from ocean water, expert says\n\nDebby has weakened over land because tropical cyclones derive their energy from warm water, but part of the circulation was still interacting Tuesday with water over the Atlantic, said Richard Pasch, a senior hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe storm's center is expected to move out over the water off the Georgia and South Carolina coast, then move back inland, so it could restrengthen, but it's not clear how much, he said.\n\nTropical storm warnings were posted from northeastern Florida up into North Carolina, and very heavy rain is expected, leading to catastrophic flooding across parts of southeastern Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina and southeastern North Carolina through Friday, he said.\n\n\"Tropical cyclones always produce heavy rain, but normally as they're moving, you know, it doesn't accumulate that much in one place,\" he said. \"But when they move very slowly, that's the worst situation.\"\n\nCharleston ready with sandbags, parking garages\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8261109246", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:36:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:36:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:35:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.kob.com/news/us-and-world-news/tropical-storm-debby-is-expected-to-send-flooding-to-the-southeast-heres-how-much-rain-could-fall/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "A home in Rubonia, Fla., is surrounded by floodwater after Tropical Storm Debby swept through the area, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, in Bradenton, Fla. (Tiffany Tompkins/The Bradenton Herald via AP)[ASSOCIATED PRESS/Tiffany Tompkins]\n\nNorthern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nHow much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit. Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina. Russ Bynum contributed from Savannah, Georgia.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-445420647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "08:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T08:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:20:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://phys.org/news/2024-08-tropical-storm-debby-southeast-fall.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "Northern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nHow much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.", "source": {"uri": "phys.org", "dataType": "news", "title":
