Storm Debby moves through US southeast", "body": "Coastal South Carolina and Georgia were under flash flood warnings Tuesday, as Tropical Storm Debby swamped the southeastern United States, leaving at least five dead.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier Monday as a Category One hurricane.\n\nAuthorities said a truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler plunged into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash in Dixie County.\n\nAs the storm moved northward into Georgia, a 19-year-old was killed when a tree fell into the side of a house, according to the Colquitt County coroner's office.\n\nEarly Tuesday morning, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) was warning of \"potentially historic heavy rainfall\" and \"catastrophic flooding\" in parts of southeast Georgia and eastern South Carolina.\n\nThe Weather Channel reported tornadoes in South Carolina overnight.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has approved emergency declarations for Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, allowing for federal assistance in coordinating disaster relief efforts.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis also activated his state's National Guard, with more than 3,000 service members mobilized to help with storm response.\n\nMore from this section Harris set to name VP pick ahead of swing state tour 4 Tips to Keeping Your Gut Healthy and Free of IBD China shrug off doping controversy, win 12 Olympic swimming medals\n\nThe governors of Georgia and South Carolina declared a state of emergency ahead of Debby's arrival.\n\nBy Tuesday morning, the NHC said the storm was registering maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 kph) as it swept through Georgia, expected to later move offshore.\n\nThe storm is set to move along the East Coast, but has already weakened after making initial landfall with sustained speeds of 80 mph (130 kph) as a Category One hurricane -- the lowest on a scale of five.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris -- the Democratic candidate in the US presidential election -- postponed events in North Carolina and Georgia this week due to the storm, according to local media reports and her campaign team.\n\nMeanwhile, the US Border Patrol announced that Debby had washed up 25 packages of cocaine worth around $1 million to the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were seized.\n\nIn July, at least 18 people were killed when the powerful Hurricane Beryl tore through the Caribbean before hitting the southern US states of Texas and Louisiana.\n\nScientists say climate change likely plays a role in the rapid intensification of storms such as Beryl because there is more "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0806/1463598-storm-debby-fatalities/", "title": "250,000 without power, 4 dead as Storm Debby hits Florida", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has drenched the US state of Florida, killing at least four people and threatening southeastern states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier yesterday as a Category One hurricane.\n\nAuthorities said a truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler plunged into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash in Dixie County.\n\nThe storm moved into Georgia overnight and is expected to go offshore before approaching the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power.\n\n\"Please, be very cautious when you're going out,\" he said, adding that Debby's winds had not been as damaging as previous hurricanes that have hit Florida.\n\nUS President Joe Biden has approved emergency declarations for Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, allowing for federal assistance in coordinating disaster relief efforts.\n\nMr DeSantis also activated his state's National Guard, with more than 3,000 service members mobilized to help with storm response.\n\nBy yesterday evening, the NHC said the storm was registering maximum sustained winds of 75km/h as it swept into Georgia.\n\nStorm surge warnings - signalling a life-threatening inundation from rising water - are in effect in parts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina.\n\nDebby was expected to bring \"potentially historic rainfall\" of up to 30 inches as it moved north, the NHC said.\n\nBut it said the storm was weakening after making landfall earlier with sustained speeds of 130km/h as a Category One hurricane - the lowest on a scale of five.\n\nMandatory evacuations were ordered for part of Citrus County, Florida, with several other counties under voluntary evacuation orders, local media reported.\n\nThe governors of Georgia and South Carolina declared a state of emergency ahead of Debby's arrival.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed events in North Carolina and Georgia this week due to the storm, according to local media reports citing her campaign team.\n\nWe need your consent to load this comcast-player contentWe use comcast-player to manage extra content that can after Storm Debby hits Florida coast", "body": "A Florida National Guard vehicle drives through a flooded street\n\nAt least four people were killed as Tropical Storm Debby drenched Florida on Monday, threatening southeastern US states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier Monday as a Category One hurricane.\n\nAuthorities said a truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler plunged into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash in Dixie County.\n\nThe storm is expected to move into Georgia overnight, before moving offshore and approaching the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power.\n\n\"Please, be very cautious when you're going out,\" he said, adding that Debby's winds had not been as damaging as previous hurricanes that have hit Florida.\n\nPresident Joe Biden on Sunday approved an emergency declaration for Florida, allowing federal aid to be expedited.\n\nDeSantis has activated the state's National Guard, with more than 3,000 service members mobilized to help with storm response.\n\n- Evacuation orders -\n\nBy late afternoon, the NHC said the storm was registering maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph) as it swept over Florida.\n\nMore from this section Iconic S.African actor John Kani awarded an OBE Thailand's Moriya fires 66 to win LPGA Portland Classic No.1 Swiatek withdraws from WTA Toronto event due to fatigue\n\nStorm surge warnings -- signalling a life-threatening inundation from rising water -- are in effect in parts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina.\n\nDebby was expected to bring \"potentially historic rainfall\" of up to 30 inches as it moved north, the NHC said.\n\nBut it said Debby was weakening after making landfall earlier with sustained speeds of 80 mph (130 kph) as a Category One hurricane -- the lowest on a scale of five.\n\nMandatory evacuations were ordered for part of Citrus County, Florida, with eight other counties under voluntary evacuation orders, local media reported.\n\nPolice in the city of Sarasota said that some 500 residents were evacuated from their flooded homes.\n\nThe governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared a state of emergency ahead of the storm's arrival.\n\nMeanwhile, the US Border Patrol announced that Debby had washed up 25 packages of cocaine to the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were seized.\n\nThe intended shipment had a street value of more than $1 million, acting chief patrol Agent Samuel Briggs II said on X.\n\nIn July, at least 18 people were killed when the powerful Hurricane Beryl tore through the Caribbean before hitting the southern US states of Texas and Louisiana.\n\nScientists say climate change likely plays a role in the rapid intensification of storms such as Beryl because there is more energy in a warmer ocean for them to feed on.\n\nbur-ia/bjt/dw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8261107499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:34:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:34:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:33:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/tropical-storm-debby-is-expected-to-send-flooding-to-the-southeast-heres-how-much-rain/article_335f9884-d6c6-5717-b324-058d2389429b.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby is expected to send flooding to the Southeast. Here's how much rain could fall", "body": "By ALEXA ST. JOHN - Associated Press\n\nNorthern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.\n\nDebby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on the Big Bend coast of Florida early Monday, first hitting the small community of Steinhatchee. It damaged homes and businesses, sent floodwaters rising, caused sweeping power outages across the state and Georgia and led to several fatalities. Debby was downgraded to a tropical storm midday Monday.\n\nBut experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.\n\nPeople are also reading... VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Platter & Pour working to open State Street location OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Viking football just means more to Tennessee High's Trent Dowdell MLB: Rangers outfielder Evan Carter (Elizabethton) likely to miss rest of regular season with back injury How much rain is expected?\n\nForecasters say the system could pummel the Southeast with widespread areas of up to 20 inches (51 centimeters) of rain and some totaling up to 30 inches (76 centimeters).\n\nThat would be a record-setting rainfall, shattering the record from a tropical system in 2018's Hurricane Florence. More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, \"It really is worthy of a Category 3 or 4 rating, if you want to talk about rainfall impacts,\" said Jeff Masters, founder of Weather Underground, now with Yale Climate Connections. \"That's going to cause a lot of damage.\"\n\nWhat areas are at risk?\n\nNorthern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding. North Carolina could also be impacted.\n\nOfficials in Savannah warned the area could see a month's worth of rain in four days if the system stalls. There were also flooding concerns for Tybee Island, Georgia's largest public beach 18 miles (28.97 kilometers) east of Savannah. On top of any torrential downpours that Debby dishes out, the island could get even wetter from 2 to 4 feet of storm surge, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Hilton Head Island Mayor Alan Perry said on a video posted to Facebook. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nFew places in South Carolina are as susceptible to flooding as Charleston. Much of the city and surrounding areas founded in 1670 were built on land created by using fill dirt and other debris. Rising sea levels cause a number of minor flooding events even without a storm and like many coastal cities, Charleston can't drain well.\n\nThe city doesn't expect a massive amount of flooding from the ocean, but the storm is still dangerous. Heavy rain can back up into the city, also causing flooding.\n\nWhat's causing this storm to stall?\n\nSome hurricanes make landfall and move quickly, experts say, while others slow substantially.\n\n\"Really what happened, and why the storm has stalled, is because there's basically high pressure areas to the west of the storm and to the northeast, and that's kind of pinned the storm,\" said Phil Klotzbach, senior research scientist at Colorado State University's Department of Atmospheric Science. \"With a hurricane you always have wind problems, but when you have a storm moving at 3 to 5 miles an hour, it's going to be over any specific location for a very long period of time, so flash flooding and just tremendous rainfall totals are going to be very likely.\"\n\nExperts say the warming atmosphere plays a role in the severity of storm surges such as Debby.\n\nWarming water in the northeast Gulf of Mexico is increasing Hurricane Debby's heavy rains, as more moisture evaporates from the waters, Masters said. Some research says climate change can impact the forward motion of hurricanes, he added, making them go slower.\n\n\"It's something we've been seeing more of lately,\" Masters said.\n\nHow long could this last?\n\nThe worst of the rain is expected during the first half of the week, but it could last through Saturday, forecasters said.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit. Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina. Russ Bynum contributed from Savannah, Georgia.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X, formerly Twitter, @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-445663369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:00:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:00:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T07:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/florida/articles/2024-08-06/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby Churns Across the US Southeast", "body": "The storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8261477232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "09:14:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T09:14:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:11:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/aug/06/tropical-storm-linked-to-5-deaths/", "title": "Tropical storm linked to 5 deaths", "body": "HORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida on Monday with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths in the state and the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes before turning menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard's low-lying regions and threatening to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nRecord-setting rain was causing flash flooding, with up to 30 inches possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Fla., a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. It was one of the cities hardest hit by flooding on Monday.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from floodwaters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, public safety director for Manatee County. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nA flash flood emergency was issued into Monday evening for the Lake City area in the north central part of the state, where up to a foot of rain had fallen and more was expected.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It since has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least five deaths.\n\nA truck driver died on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, according to the Levy County sheriff's office.\n\nAnd in Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night. The Florida Highway Patrol said a 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries.\n\nPhoto GalleryTropical Storm Debby hits Florida\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nNearly 200,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nAirports were also affected. More than 1,600 flights had been canceled nationwide, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nThe potential for high water also threatened Savannah, Ga., and Charleston, S.C.\n\nLocal leaders in Savannah said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city. With winds and rainfall expected to worsen overnight, authorities issued a curfew from 10 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Freida Frisaro, Kate Payne, Michael Schneider, Russ Bynum, Jeffrey Collins, Darlene {"uri": "8260725921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:49:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:49:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:49:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.newson6.com/story/66b132fd56876165357188a5/maps-show-tropical-storm-debbys-path-and-forecast", "title": "Maps Show Tropical Storm Debby's Path And Forecast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby was barreling across northern Florida on Monday morning after making landfall over the state's Big Bend coast as a Category 1 hurricane. Even with the slight dip in intensity, Debby was forecast to bring dangerous storm surge to parts of the Gulf Coast of Florida through Monday afternoon.\n\nTropical Storm Debby was barreling across northern Florida on Monday morning after making landfall over the state's Big Bend coast as a Category 1 hurricane. Even with the slight dip in intensity, Debby was forecast to bring dangerous storm surge to parts of the Gulf Coast of Florida through Monday afternoon.\n\nThe storm could bring historic rainfall to surrounding states like Georgia and South Carolina, too, the National Hurricane Center said, warning that Debby was expected to cause \"major flooding\" to parts of the southeastern United States over the next several days.\n\nDebby slammed into the Big Bend coast, where the Florida panhandle meets the peninsula, near Steinhatchee, a small oceanside town about 70 miles west of Gainesville, at around 7 a.m. EDT. The hurricane center said it was was tracking slightly inland in the Big Bend region about an hour after landfall, with maximum sustained winds of 75 miles per hour. That marked a marginal decrease in power, as meteorologists estimated that Debby struck the coast with 80 mph winds.\n\nBy 2 p.m., sustained wind speeds had fallen to about 65 mph, with higher gusts, as the tropical storm churned along its anticipated north-northeastern route. Meteorologists said at the time that Debby was located about 10 miles northwest of Live Oak, Florida, and traveling at around 7 mph. Tropical-storm-force winds extended outward up to 140 miles from the eye of the storm, which was expected to gradually weaken over the coming days.\n\nMeteorologists expected that storm surge would be most catastrophic in the immediate vicinity of the landfall location, with initial forecasts indicating a 130-mile stretch of coastline between Yankeetown and the Aucilla River could see surges between 6 and 10 feet above ground. Storm surge threats gradually lessened as the hours passed after Debby's landfall, with forecasters saying by the afternoon that peak surge in that region would look more like 3 to 5 feet.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center published maps on Monday illustrating the storm surge forecast.\n\nThe below map, updated on Monday afternoon, shows the highest potential values in the peak surge range, and includes the tide, the hurricane center said. Meteorologists noted that the timing of peak surge and high tide in a given area, and whether they coincide or not, will ultimately determine how destructive the inundation will be.\n\nStorm surge threats were expected to abate farther into the panhandle and down the length of the Gulf Coast -- but only somewhat. Meteorologists warned that surges as high as 3 feet could hit areas west of the Aucilla River to Indian Pass, and south of Yankeetown to Bonita Beach. That stretch includes Tampa Bay and the surrounding area. A shorter stretch of the Gulf Coast from Yankeetown to Aripeka was still at risk of slightly higher surges at 2 p.m., according to the hurricane center.\n\nCoastal places as far south as Bonita Beach could see heavy rainfall coupled with storm surge for the next several days as a result of the tropical storm. So could coastal areas along a vast stretch of the southeastern U.S., from the mouth of the St. Mary's River, around where Florida meets Georgia, up to the South Santee River in South Carolina. That southeastern stretch includes major cities in both states, Savannah and Charleston, and could weather storm surge up to 4 feet above ground as Debby continues to turn northeastward.\n\nDebby was slowing down after making landfall on Monday, and the hurricane center said that the anticipated rainfall totals along its path are so massive in part because the storm is lingering over each place it passes.\n\nAs it shifts farther east, the storm was expected to touch an expansive spread along the southeastern U.S. through the Carolinas before dissipating. In the hurricane center's most recent path forecast for Debby, meteorologists projected the storm would continue tracking across northern Florida and up through a portion of the southeastern coast of Georgia later on Monday and into Tuesday. The latest forecasts extended by 6 hours the time frame in which Debby would travel up to Georgia and the Carolinas.\n\nForecasts suggested the storm could move off a linear path again late Tuesday and Wednesday, traveling inland while continuing northward to South Carolina and then likely turning back toward the coast on Thursday.\n\nThe hurricane center had predicted that Debby would weaken rapidly after the eye of the storm moved inland into northern Florida, shifting back into a tropical storm. But meteorologists also warned that Debby could strengthen again after an initial period of weakening, depending on whether it oscillates between an inland and coastal path during its route over the southeastern states.\n\nDebby was also expected to dump heavy rain totaling 6 to 12 inches, and even as high as 18 inches in some places, across central and northern Florida as well as central and northeast North Carolina throughout the rest of the week until Saturday morning. Meteorologists warned that the rainfall would likely cause considerable flash and urban flooding, and significant river flooding, in parts of the affected states.\n\nPortions of southeast Georgia, the coastal plains of South Carolina and southeast North Carolina could see 10 to 20 inches of rainfall as Debby continues on its path, with maximum rainfall amounts as high as 30 inches, or almost three feet, in certain areas.\n\nNone of the formidable rainfall estimates or related flood warnings have changed since Debby made landfall, even after it was downgraded to a tropical storm.\n\nA handful of tornadoes could develop over central and northern Florida, as well as southeastern Georgia, on Monday, forecasters said. The tornado threat was expected to travel northeastward with the storm, into parts of South Carolina, later in the day and into Monday night.", "source": {"uri": "newson6.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-08-445658608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:57:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:57:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:41:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast/article_7a0605b2-982c-5bf7-b6ae-a3418a9d8985.html", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. {"uri": "8260735811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:00:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:00:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:59:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/08/05/metro/debby-storm-maps-new-england-rain/", "title": "Maps show Debby's forecast threat levels as storm tracks toward New England later this week - The Boston Globe", "body": "The storm made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane around 7 a.m. near Steinhatchee on Florida's Big Bend, unleashing catastrophic rainfall with damaging wind gusts over 90 miles per hour before being downgraded to a tropical storm three hours later. As Debby slows, stalling over the region, the tropical system is expected to spread record rainfall and cause severe to extreme flooding across Georgia and the Carolinas throughout the week.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby is expected to unleash up to 12 to 18 inches of rain across parts of central and northern Florida as well as parts of North Carolina through Wednesday morning.\n\nFlooding rain is the main concern. Numerous tropical and flooding alerts are in place for coastal and inland communities across Florida and into southeast Georgia and South Carolina. Debby is expected to grind to a halt and become a huge flood-maker -- copious amounts of moisture will help the storm deliver about 1 to 2 feet of rainfall across the region through Thursday.\n\nThe main cause of this torrential rain lies in Debby's interaction with a blocking high-pressure system and frontal boundary that'll slow the storm's progression to less than 5 miles per hour, where the storm will essentially hover over the Southeast.\n\nIt looks like the system will then return to warm waters just off the southeast coast, which will feed plumes of moisture to keep the system intact and the rain pouring down.\n\nNOAA's Weather Prediction Center has issued a high risk for excessive rainfall for that region. Numerous, significant flooding events will continue each day as this system crawls up the Eastern Seaboard. I would expect some areas to see localized storm totals of over 30 inches.\n\nSome areas along Florida's west coast have seen nearly a foot of rain in less than 24 hours.\n\nCedar Key along the Big Bend of Florida has seen nearly 6 feet of storm surge as Debby made landfall and will continue to see similarly strong surge through tonight.\n\nDangerous storm surge will continue to stretch along southeast shores at least through the middle of this week as Debby lingers. Florida's west coast from Naples, through Tampa, and to Indian Pass will see mostly 3 to 6 feet of inundation that will exacerbate coastal flooding.\n\nAs Debby moves closer to the Atlantic coast of Georgia and South Carolina, up to 6 feet of storm surge is expected from Jacksonville through Hilton Head, S.C.\n\nLandfall wind speeds were 80 mph with gusts well into the 90s. Tropical Storm Debby had maximum sustained winds of 65 mph as of Monday afternoon and wind speeds are expected to weaken as the system traverses over land today and Tuesday. Debby should still hold tropical storm force winds through the next few days -- which range from 39 to 73 mph.\n\nThe forecast track of the storm points to Debby bringing heavy rain to New England later this week and into the weekend.\n\nIt's still early to tell where and how Debby will move after spending the better half of a week over the Southeast, but there are some clear indicators that the track may very well take it along the Eastern Seaboard toward New England.\n\nDirect Impacts\n\nWe are likely not going to see a tropical storm, but the remnant low-pressure system of Debby will encroach near the region later this weekend. There is the chance that the center of the system may get close to New England and we can feel direct impacts from rounds of rainfall. Timing is still very early, but it looks like any direct rainfall may be Sunday into Monday.\n\nThis will depend on the strength of the Bermuda high over the northern Atlantic, which has been quite strong this summer and has been halting fronts from moving west to east over New England at a number of times this summer. This strong high may prevent Debby from meandering into the Atlantic and instead influence it's track up the coast.\n\nOur current weather pattern won't be doing us any favors. A separate front stretches west to east over the next few days and will likely cause rounds of showers and thunderstorms to soak the ground across New England. That will lower the flooding threshold later in the week when the soaking remnants of Debby arrive. These preceding storms will make marginal rainfall totals much more impactful as we move into the weekend.\n\nThis same frontal boundary will also bow to the south/southwest and likely tap into the moisture-rich environment in the Southeast where Debby is wreaking havoc.\n\nStorms love to track along frontal boundaries and this could open the faucet and invite chunks of moisture to break off from Debby and shoot into the region, despite how far south the core of the storm is located.\n\nThis means periods of steady to heavy rain may cause flooding as early as Thursday that could potentially last through Sunday as the center of the system moves closer.\n\nAs Debbie slowly tracks towards the Northeast, it will continue to weaken over land, which will reduce the forcing needed to keep a tropical system together. This will likely expand Debby's rain field across the Northeast.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": On the morning of Aug. 5, the site was bustling with people shoveling sand from depleted mounds and filling their allotted 10 bags.\n\nIt's a sign that locals are taking meteorologists' warnings seriously. Historic rainfall is on the way, and forecasters, who are notoriously judicious in their use of words, are using the term catastrophic. Ron Morales, the warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Charleston, is one of them.\n\n\"Our forecast is continuing to be 10 to 20 inches of rainfall with the event with isolated amounts up to 30 inches,\" Morales told the Berkeley Independent.\n\nHurricane Debby will churn its way up the coast at an agonizingly slow pace. Morales said models and forecasts over the past few days have all shown rain coming, and it's not going to stop. Most times, a storm will move up the East Coast in just a few days, but not this one because there are no currents to move it along.\n\n\"Think of a leaf in a river or stream that gets pushed by that stream; well, the stream basically disappears, and it doesn't push it as it gets to our area,\" he said. And so it just starts to meander and wallow around, and when it does that, it has a whole lot of moisture with it, and it just doesn't go anywhere, and it continues to rain and rain for days.\"\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nSen. Still, that event was caused by a long rain seam pushing over a smaller area. NWS numbers show the one-day total then was 9.25 inches.\n\n\"The situation is very different for the October 2015 event. It really only covered the Charleston and tri-county area versus this one, which will be in our area from the South Santee River down to the Altamaha River (GA),\" he said. \"Several counties inland in Southeast South Carolina could see these rainfall amounts. We still think the highest probability of getting those amounts would be closer to the coast.\"\n\nMorals said he is not exactly sure when the rain will eventually stop. {"uri": "8260588516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "18:35:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T18:35:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T18:34:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.news4jax.com/news/georgia/2024/08/05/historic-flooding-forecast-for-southeast-georgia-as-state-starts-to-feel-the-effects-of-debby-10-inches-expected/", "title": "'Historic' flooding forecast for Southeast Georgia as state starts to feel the effects of Debby; 10+ inches expected", "body": "ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga. - Forecasters are warning that heavy rain from Tropical Storm Debby could spawn catastrophic flooding in Georgia and surrounding states.\n\nIn Georgia, the National Weather Service is predicting major flooding on some rivers: the Canoochee River near Claxton, the Ohoopee River near Reidsville and the Ogeechee River near Eden. All those rivers were below flood stage Monday but could see their water levels more than double by later in the week.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nStorm surge is a major concern along the coast on top of the rain. Some areas are set to see 3-6 inches of rain on Monday into Tuesday and 10 or more inches over the next three days.\n\nThousands were already without power on Monday afternoon.\n\nGovernor Brian P. Kemp issued a state of emergency for all 159 Georgia counties ahead of the storm.\n\nIn Savannah, local leaders said flooding could happen in areas that don't usually get high water if Debby stalls out over the city.\n\n\"This type of rain hovering over us, coming with the intensity that they tell us it is coming, it's going to catch a whole lot of people by surprise,\" said Chatham County Chairman Chester Ellis.\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.\n\nThe city of Charleston has an emergency plan in place that includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, flooding rains fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding that nearly knocked Columbia's water system offline.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nIn Savannah, Jim Froncak piled sandbags into his pickup truck on Monday, as rain was already falling. He said a recent thunderstorm caused so much flooding that he and a friend were able to kayak down a street.\n\n\"That was just a thunderstorm,\" he said. \"So, who knows what could happen with this?\"\n\nGeorgia DOT teams statewide have equipment loaded and crews are on alert, including immediate-response strike teams ready to respond to the historic rainfall event and expected flooding in Southern and Southeastern Georgia this week. {"uri": "8261724651", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:47:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:47:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:46:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/2024/08/06/the-latest-tropical-storm-debby-churns-across-the-us-southeast", "title": "The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns across the US Southeast", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nTropical Storm Debby has moved into the U.S. Southeast with what are likely to be long torrential downpours and flooding after raking Florida with heavy rain and high winds.\n\nThe storm killed at least five people on Monday and is causing flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as well as elsewhere on the Southeast's Atlantic Coast. Savannah Mayor Van Johnson told residents to expect a rough day Tuesday. Debby made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nAlthough Debby was classified as a Category 1, which is based on wind speeds, meteorologists say it's the storm's rainfall capacity that makes it extremely dangerous.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nDebby's center was over southeastern Georgia early Tuesday with maximum sustained winds near 45 mph (75 kph), and it was moving northeast near 7 mph (11 kph). The center is expected to move off Georgia's coast later Tuesday. Some strengthening is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nThe emergency plan in the city of Charleston, South Carolina, includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters, and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed by flooding.\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.", "source": {"uri": "winnipegfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Winnipeg Free Press"}, "authors": Monday, threatening southeastern US states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier Monday as a Category One hurricane.\n\nAuthorities said a truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler plunged into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash in Dixie County.\n\nThe storm is expected to move into Georgia overnight, before moving offshore and approaching the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power.\n\n\"Please, be very cautious when you're going out,\" he said, adding that Debby's winds had not been as damaging as previous hurricanes that have hit Florida.\n\nPresident Joe Biden on Sunday approved an emergency declaration for Florida, allowing federal aid to be expedited.\n\nDeSantis has activated the state's National Guard, with more than 3,000 service members mobilized to help with storm response.\n\n- Evacuation orders -\n\nBy late afternoon, the NHC said the storm was registering maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph) as it swept over Florida.\n\nStorm surge warnings -- signalling a life-threatening inundation from rising water -- are in effect in parts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina.\n\nDebby was expected to bring \"potentially historic rainfall\" of up to 30 inches as it moved north, the NHC said.\n\nBut it said Debby was weakening after making landfall earlier with sustained speeds of 80 mph (130 kph) as a Category One hurricane -- the lowest on a scale of five.\n\nMandatory evacuations were ordered for part of Citrus County, Florida, with eight other counties under voluntary evacuation orders, local media reported.\n\nPolice in the city of Sarasota said that some 500 residents were evacuated from their flooded homes.\n\nThe governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared a state of emergency ahead of the storm's arrival.\n\nMeanwhile, the US Border Patrol announced that Debby had washed up 25 packages of cocaine to the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were seized.\n\nThe intended shipment had a street value of more than $1 million, acting chief patrol Agent Samuel Briggs II said on X.\n\nIn July, at least 18 people were killed when the powerful Hurricane Beryl tore through the Caribbean before hitting the southern US states of Texas and Louisiana.\n\nScientists say climate change likely plays a role in the rapid intensification of storms such as Beryl because there is more energy in a warmer ocean for them to feed on.\n\nbur-ia/bjt/dw\n\nMore from this section\n\nGoogle illegally maintains monopoly over internet search, judge rules\n\nReformed Gangster Disciples Boss, Harold 'Noonie G' Ward Hosts Citywide Voter Registration Drive During the DNC in Support of VP Kamala {"uri": "2024-08-444998917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:18:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:18:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:18:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/688050/international/debby-soaks-northern-florida-eyes-georgia-next", "title": "Debby soaks northern Florida, eyes Georgia next", "body": "A drone view shows houses and streets flooded as Hurricane Debby affects the gulf coast in Suwannee, Florida, yesterday. (Reuters)\n\nTropical Storm Debby dropped buckets of rain across northern Florida yesterday afternoon as it plodded toward Georgia and the Carolinas, where forecasters expect the downgraded hurricane to bring a week of torrential downpours and catastrophic flooding.\n\nThe storm had lost some of its windspeed after slamming Florida's Gulf Coast around 7am last morning as a Category 1 hurricane. It made landfall near Steinhatchee, in the Big Bend region about 70 miles southeast of Tallahassee, delivering winds of up to 80mph, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe hurricane centre predicted Debby would move offshore into the Atlantic by Tuesday night, then re-strengthen and come back inland to drench the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina later in the week.\n\nThe centre forecast \"catastrophic flooding,\" with local areas along Georgia and South Carolina's coastline receiving 20 to 30 inches of rain by Friday morning. The governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared states of emergency in anticipation of Debby's damage.\n\n\"This is going to be an event that is going to be probably here for the next five to seven days, maybe as long as 10 days, depending on how much rainfall we get,\" said Florida Division of Emergency Management Executive Director Kevin Guthrie.\n\nBy midday yesterday, Debby had already dumped eight to 16 inches of rain in some parts of central Florida, according to local weather reports.\n\nHours after the storm's landfall in Steinhatchee, heavy rains were still falling on the beach town, and bayfront restaurants were flooded. Further south in Hillsborough County, rescue crews in Tampa recovered the body of an 18-wheeler truck driver who had lost control of the vehicle on Interstate 75 and went into the Tampa Bypass Canal, local TV station WTSP reported.\n\nRoughly 240,000 customers were without power in Florida, according to Poweroutage.us, and flight trackers showed hundreds of flights originating from and heading to Florida airports were cancelled yesterday.\n\nA slow-moving tropical storm as it passed over Cuba, Debby gained strength from exceptionally warm Gulf waters as it paralleled Florida's Gulf Coast on Sunday.\n\nDebby bears some of the hallmarks of Hurricane Harvey, which hit Corpus Christi, Texas, in August 2017. Downgraded to a tropical storm as it moved inland, Harvey lingered over Texas, dumping about 50 inches of rain on Houston and causing $125bn in damage.\n\nClimate scientists believe man-made global warming from burning fossil fuels has raised the temperature of the oceans, making storms bigger and more devastating. The last hurricane to make a direct hit on the Big Bend region was Hurricane Idalia, which briefly gained Category 4 strength before making landfall as a Category 3 in August 2023, with winds of more than 125mph.\n\nThe National Centers for Environmental Information estimated $3.5bn in damages. DeSantis described the initial effects of Debby as \"modest\" compared with Idalia.\n\nForecasters expect numerous Atlantic hurricanes in the 2024 season, which began on June 1, including four to seven major ones. That would exceed the record-breaking 2005 season that spawned the devastating Katrina and Rita hurricanes.\n\nOnly one hurricane, Beryl, has yet formed in the Atlantic this year. The earliest Category 5 storm on record, it struck the Caribbean and Mexico's Yucatan peninsula before rolling up the Gulf Coast of Texas as a Category 1 storm, with sustained winds up to 95mph.", {"uri": "8260752759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:18:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:18:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:17:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.nj.com/weather/2024/08/tropical-storm-debby-on-track-to-dump-heavy-rain-on-nj-region-after-pounding-southeast.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby on track to dump heavy rain on N.J. region after pounding Southeast", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby continues to swirl slowly in the southeastern U.S. Monday evening after causing widespread flooding and killing four people in Florida. And even though it's more than 800 miles away from New Jersey, the storm has the potential to dump heavy rain on the Garden State later this week into the early weekend.\n\nThat's the latest prediction by weather forecasters, who say New Jersey also faces a threat of street flooding and river flooding from a different storm system on Tuesday and Wednesday.\n\nThe first batch of rain will be triggered by a cold front that will be moving in from the northwest and is expected to slow down or stall near the Mid-Atlantic coast, forecasters said. Although the front is not related to Tropical Storm Debby, southerly winds could push tropical moisture up north, boosting the amount of potential rain affecting New Jersey during the next several days.\n\nOn Tuesday and Wednesday, flash flooding is possible in urban areas and places with poor drainage, prompting the National Weather Service to issue a flood watch for 15 New Jersey counties -- Bergen, Burlington, Camden, Essex, Gloucester, Hudson, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Ocean, Passaic, Salem, Somerset and Union.\n\nThe flood watch is active from 2 p.m. Tuesday through noon Wednesday in Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Passaic and Union counties, and 5 p.m. Tuesday through 8 a.m. Wednesday in the other counties. counties.\n\nAs of 5 p.m. Monday, the center of Tropical Storm Debby was lingering in northern Florida and slowly moving north-northeast into southern Georgia, according to the National Hurricane Center. The storm's center was located about 30 miles southeast of Valdosta, Georgia.\n\nDebby, which made landfall in the Big Bend region of Florida Monday morning as a Category 1 hurricane with top winds of 80 mph, was packing sustained winds up to 50 mph as of 5 p.m.\n\nThe storm's biggest threat continues to be its immense amount of moisture and slow movement, which is allowing bands of heavy rain to fall on the same general areas of Florida and Georgia, forecasters say.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says as much as 12 to 16 inches of rain could drench southeastern Georgia and the coastal plain of South Carolina during the next five days, and southern and southeastern sections of North Carolina could get hit with up to 12 to 16 inches of rain in the next five days.\n\nAs much as 6 to 12 inches of rain is possible across a wide swath of central North Carolina, according to a latest forecast map from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nSome forecasters in the New Jersey region say the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby could bring anywhere from 3 to 8 inches of rain to the Garden State, along with the New York City and Philadelphia metro areas, later this week into early this weekend. However, there's a slight chance the heaviest bands of rain could move farther east, out over the Atlantic Ocean, instead of drifting directly over land.\n\nThe exact track of the storm and its remnants won't be known until Debby moves through Georgia and the Carolinas -- a trek that might be a long one because the storm is expected to stall out or move very slowly between Tuesday morning and Thursday morning.\n\nOfficials in Florida say four people, including two youths, have been killed in incidents related to Debby.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree fell onto a mobile home near Gainesville, and a car crash linked to the stormy weather claimed the life of a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy, according to reports by NBC News and 7-News in South Carolina.\n\nAlso, the driver of a semi-truck died after his vehicle veered out of control on a wet highway and the cab was submerged in a canal near Interstate 75 near Tampa, 7-News reported.\n\nMore than 300,000 utility customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nThank you for relying on us to provide the local weather news you can trust. Ron DeSantis said at least four deaths have been linked to Debby.\n\nTwo people were killed in a crash in Dixie County while one person was killed in a crash in Hillsborough County, DeSantis said.\n\nIn Levy County, officials said a tree fell over onto a mobile home, crushing and killing a 13-year-old boy who was inside.\n\nAround 250,000 customers were without power in Florida on Monday morning, while around 450,000 accounts had been restored, DeSantis said.\n\nIn Marion County, which is inland and south of Gainesville, sheriff's officials noted in a Facebook post Monday that crews were responding to reports of downed power lines and trees that have fallen on roadways and homes.\n\nDeSantis said some 17,000 linemen are working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to sit tight until conditions are safe.\n\n\"When the water rises, when you have streets that can be flooded, that's hazardous,\" DeSantis said. \"Don't try to drive through this. We don't want to see traffic fatalities adding up. Don't tempt fate, don't try to go through these flooded streets.\"\n\nIn Union County, some roads were already under water and numerous trees and powerlines were down. The Union County Sheriff's Office said Monday that residents were cleaning up from a tornado that touched down in the county Sunday night, damaging at least one home. No injuries were reported.\n\nHurricane Debby has followed a track \"very similar to Idalia 11 months ago,\" DeSantis said. Idalia came ashore near Keaton Beach, Florida on Aug. 30, 2023, with maximum sustained winds of 125 mph. Keaton Beach is about 20 miles north of Steinhatchee. He noted there were fewer power outages with Debby.\n\nImages posted on social media by Cedar Key Fire Rescue early Monday showed floodwaters rising along the streets of the city, located south of where the storm made landfall. Water was \"coming in at a pretty heavy pace,\" the post said.\n\nIn Live Oak, the roof of a warehouse was partially torn off, as pieces of metal from the structure were scattered on the street. Police were also blocking off several roads that had been flooded.\n\nCrews from all over the state responded to help out, including Miami-Dade Fire Rescue, who sent around 50 personnel including rescue specialists, K-9 search teams, engineers and medical workers.\n\nOfficials in Venice posted photos of a roadway left damaged by the hurricane.\n\n\"Right now, we are to trying secure everything from floating away,\" said Sheryl Horne, whose family owns the Shell Island Fish Camp along the Wakulla River in St. Marks, Florida, where some customers moved their boats inland.\n\nThe sparsely populated Big Bend region in the Florida Panhandle also was hit last year by Hurricane Idalia, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.\n\n\"I am used to storms and I'm used to cleaning up after storms,\" Horne said.\n\n\"We're all hanging on here - a bunch of us stayed,\" Dawn Perez said Monday by phone, as the eyewall of Hurricane Debby bore down on her home in the small town of Perry, Florida. Perez, the director of the town's tourism department, said she has a new roof after Hurricane Idalia tore it apart in August 2023.\n\n\"The winds are intense - I've already lost my porch door and a tree, and stuff is blowing all over the place,\" Perez said.\n\nDebby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Towns in Georgia and South Carolina have imposed curfews.\n\nCrews in places like Savannah, Georgia, are standing by to deploy high-water rescue boats in cases of emergency.\n\nIn Charleston, South Carolina, residents were seen stacking sandbags as they braced for the potentially historic and catastrophic flooding.\n\nRELATED STORY | What is the difference between a tropical storm and hurricane?\n\nA flooding threat from Georgia through South Carolina and parts of North Carolina will last through Thursday.\n\nIn Florida, over 116,000 were without power as of 7 a.m. Tuesday, according to PowerOutage.us. As the storm kept moving, over 25,000 were without power in Georgia and nearly 17,000 were in the dark in South Carolina.\n\nCrews in Florida will attempt to restore power and clear roadways on Tuesday now that the storm has moved out of the state.\n\nDebby also disrupted travel. Over 9,000 flights within, into, or out of the U.S. on Monday were delayed, and nearly 2,000 flights were canceled, according to FlightAware. {"uri": "8261578163", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:15:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:15:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:14:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://abc11.com/post/hurricane-debby-north-carolina-flooding-rain-storm-2024-tropical-weather-path/15149324/", "title": "Bands of rain from Tropical Storm Debby will appear Tuesday in NC", "body": "RALEIGH, N.C. (WTVD) -- Rain from Tropical Storm Debby will start to fall on Tuesday afternoon, before bringing even more rain Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is predicting the eye of the storm to sit in the Atlantic Ocean before moving north through South Carolina and into North Carolina this weekend.\n\nAs Debby slowly approaches, central North Carolina will experience rounds of rain and increasingly gusty winds Tuesday through Friday. There's already a high risk of flooding in areas that have experienced rain in the past few weeks.\n\nBeach erosion is also expected at the coast.\n\nThere is a high risk for Raleigh and counties to the south to experience flash flooding.\n\nStorm totals could be 8 to 12 inches in the Sandhills and the Triangle could see 6 to 9 inches by Friday night.\n\nDebby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.\n\nState agencies are already preparing for the storm and its impact on the state. Gov. Roy Cooper declared a State of Emergency ahead of the storm -- a move that activates state emergency plans in various industries.\n\n\"This weather has the potential to bring intense rain and flooding to North Carolina and we are preparing for it,\" Cooper said. \"As the weather becomes more severe, I urge everyone to take precautions and stay safe.\"\n\nFlooding and power outages are expected to start Tuesday and continue through the rest of the week, according to North Carolina Emergency Management officials.\n\nWATCH: Special Debby edition of The Weather Show\n\nThe City of Raleigh announced on Sunday that it started lowering Lake Johnson in anticipation of the heavy rainfall from the storm system.\n\nIn Wake County, preparations for Debbie are underway in a community still cleaning up from a natural disaster. In the Woodlands community in Garner - which was rocked by an EF-1 tornado in December - several residents said they're bracing for this week's expected rainfall.\n\nJanice Hedgepeth said the memory of that vicious storm in December is still vivid.\n\n\"Everything was everywhere. And we thought, you know, maybe that was it. A few limbs and stuff. But as we walked around and looked around, neighbor's roofs were gone. It was it was horrible,\" she said.\n\nHedgepeth, who's lived in the community for three decades, said she's endured several hurricanes and always tries to stay stocked with supplies.\n\n\"Ever since we went through Fran, we always take preparations. We always have water and batteries and things like that,\" she said.\n\nMeantime, hardware and home improvement stores in the area are already stocking up on supplies to help with possible flooding and power outages.\n\n\"It's mostly getting things out that they would need before a storm, and making sure we're ready if anything bad does happen,\" said Brian Edwards, store manager at Lowe's in Garner.\n\nEdwards and his team helped in the cleanup effort in the Woodlands neighborhood last year, and he said they're prepared to do the same should flooding or damage occur in the area.\n\n\"We'll get together a team and we'll see where we're needed and what we can do. And, you know, any kind of labor or anything we can do to help out the people around here is what we're going to do,\" he said.\n\nDebby is expected to move eastward back into the Atlantic before heading north up through South Carolina\n\nNorth Carolina officials are also monitoring the storm's progress, as it could turn north after tracking along the South Carolina coast. That change in direction would send the system right through the heart of the Tar Heel state.\n\nForecasters say Debby's biggest effects could be as much as 30 inches of rain in localized areas throughout South Carolina, causing floodwaters to rise quickly in small areas.\n\n\"This storm may not have the high winds of a hurricane, but it has the potential to cause life-threatening floods across the state. And I would like to emphasize that Tropical Storm Debby is not just a coastal event, but it is a statewide event,\" South Carolina Emergency Management Division Director Kim Stenson said at a Monday afternoon news conference.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, flooding rains fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding that nearly knocked Columbia's water system offline.\n\nIn 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in {"uri": "2024-08-445271674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:50:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:50:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:36:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/national/article290783199.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby: At least 5 dead, 177,000 without power in Florida", "body": "Aug. 5 (UPI) -- At least five people have died as slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby slammed into northern Florida's Big Bend area on Monday as a Category 1 storm and then moved into Georgia.\n\nDebby, packing sustained winds of 80 mph, dumped dumped torrential rain across northern Florida along with life-threatening winds. It reached land at 7 a.m.\n\nIdalia hit a similar area as Category 3 hurricane last August.\n\nThe storm was downgraded to a tropical storm at 11 a.m. EDT.\n\nFour deaths were reported in Florida and one in Georgia.\n\nAt about 8 a.m., EDT, a tree fell on a mobile Home in Levy County, killing a 13-year-old boy who was hunkered down inside with his family. The county's sheriff's department said the boy was crushed by the tree that severely damaged the home.\n\nThere was no report of anyone else being injured in the incident.\n\nTwo people, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy, died Sunday night in Dixie County after the vehicle they were in overturned on U.S.19 while driving through heavy rain produced by Debby. A 14-year-old boy was transported to the University of Florida Health with serious injuries.\n\nThe cab of a tractor-trailer fell into the water at the Tampa Bypass Canal early Monday after losing control, killing the driver after being found later Monday morning, Florida Highway Patrol said. The semi was southbound on I-75 when it lost control and hit a barrier before its cab fell into the canal.\n\nA 19-year-old teenager died in Moultrie, Ga., after a tree fell on the side of a house Monday afternoon, according to Colquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock. Moultrie is located about 200 miles south of Atlanta.\n\nAs Debby slows down, it is expected to bring heavy flooding from heavy rain in Florida and Georgia on Monday with some forecasts predicting up to 20 inches in Savannah, Ga.\n\nDebby created havoc on power, with PowerOutage.us reporting 300,714 locations without power in Florida and another 24,880 in Georgia early Monday. The numbers were down to 149,392 in Florida and 24,382 in Georgia at 8:30 p.m.\n\nPackages with 70 pounds of cocaine washed up on a Key West Beach , a top official with the U.S. Border Patrol said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who declared a state emergency in 61 of 67 counties on Thursday, said damage assessment teams will be in the field Tuesday.\n\nDebby \"did not bring the catastrophic hurricane-force winds that we've seen in previous storms like Hurricane Ian and Michael, but it has and continues to produce lots of water,\" DeSantis said at the state's Emergency Operations Center in Tallahassee.\n\n\"We are going to see flooding, particularly in the northern part of the state, (so) be very careful. Don't go out into flood waters. There can be hazards, debris and downed electrical cables. Please do not go driving if roads are underwater.\"\n\nAs of 3 p.m. Monday, all airports in the state were open.\n\nOn Monday, President Joe Biden approved emergency declaration requests from South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster and Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp. Earlier Biden approved a declaration for Florida.\n\nNorth Carolina Gov. {"uri": "8261152721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:15:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:15:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:15:15Z", "dataType": "news", "MIAMI: At least four people were killed as Tropical Storm Debby drenched Florida on Monday (Aug 5), threatening southeastern US states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier Monday as a Category One hurricane.\n\nAuthorities said a truck driver was killed after his 18-wheeler plunged into a canal in Hillsborough County, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy died in a car crash in Dixie County.\n\nThe storm moved into Georgia overnight and is expected to go offshore before approaching the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power.\n\n\"Please, be very cautious when you're going out,\" he said, adding that Debby's winds had not been as damaging as previous hurricanes that have hit Florida.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has approved emergency declarations for Florida and South Carolina, allowing for federal assistance in coordinating disaster relief efforts.\n\nDeSantis also activated his state's National
