{"uri": "2024-08-444843669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:37:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:37:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:31:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2024/08/05/debby-forecast-cities-florida-georgia-south-carolina/", "title": "How will Debby affect your area? See the forecast for 10 cities.", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nDebby made landfall Monday morning along Florida's Big Bend as a Category 1 storm. More than 30 million people are under alerts across much of Florida, southeast Georgia and South Carolina for wind, storm surge or flooding, even as Debby transitioned from a hurricane to a tropical storm.\n\nDebby's winds, which gusted as high as 98 mph near its landfall location, will weaken as the storm continues to move inland. However, the storm will transition into a \"potentially historic\" tropical rainstorm with devastating flooding, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nConfidence in the storm's track and impacts through Tuesday is fairly high. As Debby's low-pressure center moves through northeast Florida on Monday afternoon, and into southern Georgia on Monday evening, the heavy rain and flooding will ease along Florida's Gulf Coast but continue around Jacksonville, Fla., and spread northward, reaching Savannah, Ga., and Charleston, S.C.\n\nWind gusts up to near 60 mph are possible across southern Georgia and in central to southern South Carolina, and there could be a storm surge -- the rise in ocean water above normally dry land -- of up to 4 feet in some locations along the Georgia and South Carolina coastlines. Severe thunderstorms and isolated tornadoes are possible, as well.\n\nHeavy rain and flooding, however, remain the storm's greatest threat. Many places could see 10 or more inches of rain through Tuesday. Beyond Tuesday, the forecast becomes much less certain, as models continue to struggle with whether, and exactly where, the storm will stall near the Southeast coast. Some parts of Georgia and South Carolina could end up with 20 to 30 inches of rain, challenging state records.\n\nHere are forecast details for a selection of cities in the storm's path, all of which could experience areas of flooding:\n\nTampa Bay\n\nRain and storms: Periods of moderate to heavy rain, thunderstorms and a chance of isolated tornadoes continue into Monday afternoon and night. Scattered showers and storms remain possible at times Tuesday into Wednesday. Some spots could see an additional 3 to 5 inches of rain, bringing storm totals to around 8 to 12 inches.\n\nFlood threat: Moderate.\n\nWind: Sustained winds at 20 to 30 mph on Monday afternoon, gusting to 40 to 60 mph. Sustained winds should decrease to 15 to 25 mph Monday night, with gusts of 30 to 40 mph. Occasional gusts continue near 30 mph on Tuesday.\n\nStorm surge: Storm surge along the coast could reach 3 to 5 feet through Tuesday morning.\n\nJacksonville\n\nRain and storms: Heavy rain, thunderstorms and possible tornadoes Monday afternoon and night, then occasional showers and thunderstorms through Tuesday night. Storm total rainfall through Tuesday night of 6 to 12 inches. If the storm stalls, then more periods of heavy rain could continue through at least Wednesday, potentially bringing total rainfall to 8 to 14 inches.\n\nFlood threat: Moderate.\n\nWind: Sustained winds at 20 to 35 mph on Monday afternoon and evening, gusting to 35 to 55 mph. Sustained winds should decrease to 15 to 30 mph on Tuesday, gusting 30 to 40 mph.\n\nSavannah\n\nRain and storms: Heavy rain, thunderstorms and possible tornadoes Monday afternoon and night, then periods of rain Tuesday and Wednesday. Total rainfall through Wednesday of 10 to 15 inches. If the storm stalls, then more rain in possible through at least Thursday, potentially increasing total rainfall to near or over 20 inches.\n\nFlood threat: High.\n\nWind: Sustained winds at 15 to 30 mph Monday afternoon through Tuesday. Gusts increase from 20 to 35 mph Monday afternoon to 35 to 50 mph Monday evening through Tuesday. There could also be periods of weaker winds as the calmer eye of the storm passes overhead.\n\nStorm surge: Storm surge of 2 to 4 feet at the coast starting Monday evening.\n\nCharleston\n\nRain and storms: Periods of moderate to heavy rain with thunderstorms Monday afternoon through Wednesday. Total rainfall of 8 to 14 inches through Wednesday. If the storm stalls, then more periods rain could continue through at least Thursday, potentially bringing total rainfall to near or over 20 inches.\n\nFlood threat: High.\n\nWind: Sustained winds increase to 15 to 25 mph Monday night, gusting to 25 to 35 mph. Tuesday winds should be sustained at 20 to 30 mph, gusting to 35 to 50 mph.\n\nStorm surge: Storm surge of 2 to 4 feet at the coast starting Monday evening.\n\nColumbia, S.C.\n\nRain and storms: Rain develops Monday night, occasionally heavy with thunderstorms Tuesday into Wednesday. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches through Wednesday. If the storm stalls, periods of rain could continue Thursday and possibly into Friday, increasing storm total rainfall to 4 to 8 inches.\n\nFlood threat: High.\n\nWind: Sustained winds at 15 to 30 mph Tuesday into Wednesday, gusting to 30 to 55 mph.\n\nForecast for the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast\n\nWhat happens to the north, in the Mid-Atlantic and the Northeast, will depend on the ultimate track and speed of the storm. Models still differ on whether the storm will get pulled northward by the jet stream later this week and how fast. Some suggest it could meander and eventually dissipate over or near the southeastern United States.\n\nIf the storm does come north, these are potential impacts:\n\nRaleigh, N.C.: Rain develops Tuesday and could continue at times through Friday. Near or over 5 inches of rain and moderate flooding is possible depending on the exact track and speed of the storm.\n\nVirginia Beach: Rain develops Tuesday afternoon and could continue, moderate to heavy at times, into Friday night. Around 2 to 4 inches of rain, areas of flooding and a storm surge along the coast are possible.\n\nD.C., Philadelphia and New York: If the storm takes a track up the coast, then the Interstate 95 corridor from D.C. to New York could see periods of moderate to heavy rain Thursday into Saturday, as well as localized areas of flooding. Coastal areas could see flooding, rough waves and dangerous rip currents.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": The center of the storm is \"expected to move offshore the coast of Georgia later today, drift offshore through early Thursday, and then move inland over South Carolina on Thursday,\" according to the hurricane center.\n\nAt least four deaths in Florida have been linked to Debby, which made landfall in the state's Big Bend coast on Monday morning.\n\nOn Sunday night, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy were killed in a car crash in Dixie County, with witnesses saying the car lost control due to the wet road and inclement road, according WJXT-TV. Cooper declares state of emergency", "body": "The Duke and Durham communities may see impacts from Tropical Storm Debby this week, including heavy rainfall, possible flooding and power outages.\n\nThe storm made landfall in western Florida as a Category 1 hurricane around 7 a.m. Monday morning but was downgraded to a tropical storm by 11 a.m. The storm was responsible for four deaths in Florida and one in Georgia as of Monday evening.\n\nDebby is following a northeastern path and is projected to cross through Georgia and South Carolina in the coming days. Much of North Carolina is expected to see heavy rainfall Tuesday through Friday as a result of the storm, but a potential northern turn could redirect Debby into the center of the state.\n\nGov. Roy Cooper issued a state of emergency Monday afternoon, citing \"the potential for life-threatening flash flooding, riverine flooding, wind gusts up to 40 mph, coastal impacts and other effects.\"\n\n\"As the weather becomes more severe, I urge everyone to take precautions and stay safe,\" Cooper said.\n\nCooper's executive order activates the State Emergency Operations Plan and empowers the N.C. Department of Transportation and N.C. Department of Public Safety to \"take the appropriate action\" to facilitate recovery efforts.\n\nNorth Carolina is bracing for flooding impacts, with parts of the state expected to receive 10 to 20 inches of rainfall. The city of Raleigh began lowering the water level of Lake Johnson Sunday in anticipation of the influx.\n\nA Monday afternoon advisory from the National Hurricane Center placed the Raleigh-Durham area at \"moderate risk\" -- at least 40% -- of flash flooding and cautioned the region's residents against \"dangerous storm surge.\"\n\nDebby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic season, following Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris.\n\nAlthough University administration has not made a statement about possible impacts to campus operations, Duke's Emergency Management website lists a number of resources in the event of extreme weather.\n\nThe site advises community members to monitor local news and the DukeALERT website for the most updated information. {"uri": "8261107500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:34:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:34:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:33:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/slow-moving-tropical-storm-debby-bringing-torrential-rains-major-flood-threat-to-southeastern-us/article_55966294-3ae6-5596-bdc6-6831a2db7940.html", "title": "Slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains, major flood threat to southeastern US", "body": "Passengers wait in line at American Airlines in Terminal B at the Philadelphia International Airport, Monday morning, Aug. 5, 2024, as they deal with cancelled flights to the south due to Hurricane Debby.\n\nBy JEFF MARTIN and CHRISTOPHER O'MEARA - Associated Press\n\nHORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby moved menacingly into some of America's most historic Southern cities and was expected to bring prolonged downpours and flooding throughout the day Tuesday after slamming into Florida and prompting the rescue of hundreds from flooded homes.\n\nRecord-setting rain from the storm that killed at least five people on Monday was causing flash flooding, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) possible in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\n\"Hunker down,\" Van Johnson, the mayor of Savannah, Georgia, told residents in a social media livestream Monday night. \"Expect that it will be a rough day\" on Tuesday, he said.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued in Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, among other areas of coastal Georgia and South Carolina. Both Savannah and Charleston announced curfews Monday night into Tuesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Platter & Pour working to open State Street location OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Viking football just means more to Tennessee High's Trent Dowdell MLB: Rangers outfielder Evan Carter (Elizabethton) likely to miss rest of regular season with back injury\n\nIn South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a \"historic and potentially unprecedented event\" three times in a 90-second briefing Monday.\n\nIn addition to the curfew, the city of Charleston's emergency plan includes sandbags for residents, opening parking garages so residents can park their cars above floodwaters and an online mapping system that shows which roads are closed due to flooding.\n\nIn Edisto Beach, South Carolina, a tornado touched down Monday night, damaging trees, homes and taking down power lines, the Colleton County Sheriff's Office said on social media. No injuries were immediately reported, officials said.\n\nThe National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings well into Monday night for parts of the state including in the island town of Hilton Head.\n\nDebby made landfall along the Gulf Coast of Florida early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane. It has weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, drenching and bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of eastern Georgia, the coastal plain of South Carolina and southeast North Carolina through Wednesday.\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued Monday from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said in a social media post. Just north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said on social media.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that the state could continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" he said. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nFive people had died due to the storm as of Monday night, including a truck driver on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over the edge before the cab dropped into the water below. Sheriff's office divers located the driver, a 64-year-old man from Mississippi, in the cab 40 feet (12 meters) below the surface, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office. In Dixie County, just east of where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy died in a car crash on wet roads Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, a 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.\n\nNearly 160,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday night, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were also canceled nationwide on Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com.\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved a request from South Carolina's governor for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp said he has asked Biden to issue a preemptive federal emergency declaration to speed the flow of federal aid to the state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris postponed a campaign stop scheduled for Thursday in Savannah.\n\nNorth Carolina is also under a state of emergency after Gov. Roy Cooper declared it in an executive order signed Monday. Several areas along the state's coastline are prone to flooding, such as Wilmington and the Outer Banks, according to the North Carolina Floodplain Mapping Program.\n\nNorth Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.\n\nIn 2015, rainfall fed by moisture as Hurricane Joaquin passed well offshore caused massive flooding. In 2016, flooding from Hurricane Matthew caused 24 deaths in the two states and rivers set record crests. Those records were broken in 2018 with Hurricane Florence, which set rainfall records in both Carolinas, flooded many of the same places and was responsible for 42 deaths in North Carolina and nine in South Carolina.\n\nMartin reported from Atlanta. AP journalists Freida Frisaro in Fort Lauderdale, Florida; Kate Payne in Tallahassee, Florida; Michael Schneider in Orlando, Florida; Russ Bynum in Savannah, Georgia; Jeffrey Collins in Columbia, South Carolina; Darlene Superville and Will Weissert in Washington, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8260944101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:49:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:49:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:19:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/deadly-debby-back-tropical-storm-011400069.html", "title": "Deadly Debby back to tropical storm as it moves inland, but flooding still a threat", "body": "ORLANDO, Fla. -- Hurricane Debby made landfall on Florida's Big Bend early Monday before dropping back down to a tropical storm as it moved inland, according to the National Hurricane Center. At least four people have died from either fallen trees or car crashes since the storm moved up through the Gulf of Mexico lashing the state with wind and rain over the weekend.\n\nWhat had been a tropical storm most of Sunday formed into a Category 1 hurricane before midnight, and continued to intensify overnight making landfall near Steinhatchee with sustained winds of 80 mph around 7 a.m. Eastern time and reported gusts of up to 95 mph.\n\nThe path fell just 15 miles south of where Hurricane Idalia struck in 2023.\n\nAs of 8 p.m. the NHC reported that Debby, which had reduced its intensity back to a tropical storm by 11 a.m., had further diminished strength as it moved inland with 45 mph sustained winds about 50 miles east of Valdosta, Georgia. It had slowed as well moving northeast at 6 mph. Debby's tropical-storm-force winds extend out 140 miles from the storm's center.\n\nThe outer bands to the east of Debby's center had spawned several tornado warnings across Florida overnight as the storm churned north. Southwest Orange County, including Disney World, fell under a tornado warning Monday, indicated by radar, but no funnel cloud was spotted.\n\nA late Sunday tornado warning was issued in Cocoa, and the winds flipped five campers on their side at an RV park, according to Orlando Sentinel news partner Spectrum News 13. At least one resident was transported to an area hospital.\n\nThe storm had already sent storm surge to flood the coastal areas of cities from Fort Myers north to the Panhandle while much of the west coast endured power outages, downed trees and some structural damage as the storm progressed north on Sunday.\n\nImages posted on social media by Cedar Key Fire Rescue early Monday showed floodwaters rising along the streets of the city, located south of where the storm made landfall. Water was \"coming in at a pretty heavy pace,\" the post said.\n\nDuring a press conference Monday afternoon from the Emergency Operations Center in Tallahassee, Gov. Ron DeSantis said the Florida Department of Emergency Management was well prepared to react to the system, which was much less harrowing that 2023's Hurricane Idalia and 2022's Hurricane Ian.\n\n\"We will not even scratch the surface of needing to use what was mobilized, and I think that's the way to do it,\" he said. \"We want to make sure that we're prepared for the worst and we hope for the best. You never want to have a storm but compared to Ian and even Idalia, this one is not leaving the same destruction in its wake.\"\n\nFDEM has already completed 435 storm-related missions, including requests for things like high-water vehicles or pumps, and is in the midst of completing about 400 more, he said.\n\n\"We know there's a lot of water. We know that presents hazards and we'll be ready to work accordingly,\" he said. \"There is going to be damage from the storm. There has been. There will be, but compared to some of the things that I think Floridians have been used to in the last five or 10 years, this is not Hurricane Michael. This is not Hurricane Ian.\"\n\nWhile wind and storm surge were the immediate threat, flooding remains a major concern in the days to come, said DeSantis said during a Monday morning news conference as the hurricane was moving ashore.\n\n\"This storm has produced and will likely produce significant flooding events from Sarasota-Bradenton area all the way up to northern Florida,\" he said. \"There's a threat, ongoing threat of that, over the ensuing days.\"\n\nHe urged at the time for Floridians to remain inside.\n\n\"Don't go out into the storm. Don't drive on the roads, particularly when they're flooded,\" he said noting some traffic accidents already across the state that might be blamed on the hurricane when an official death toll is taken.\n\nOne semi truck, the driver of which was found dead inside the cab of the vehicle, had veered off a bridge into the water off Interstate 75 in Tampa, according to the Florida Highway Patrol. FHP also reported another two-car crash in Dixie County on Sunday night that left two people dead and one person hospitalized stating witnesses said it looked like one of the vehicles had lost control because of a wet roadway and inclement weather.\n\n\"When you have flood situations, that is the No. 1 way where we will see fatalities is by people being out on the roads and hydroplaning or having other problems,\" he said. \"So do not go walk or drive into flooded roadways. There are hazards there. They're dangerous. We want everybody to be safe.\"\n\nAnother death was reported by the Levy County Sheriff's Office, which confirmed a 13-year-old boy had been crushed inside a mobile home that was hit by a fallen tree in Fanning Springs on Monday morning.\n\nThe governor had declared a state of emergency last week to most of the state's counties, and President Joe Biden approved the Federal Emergency Management Agency to coordinate all disaster relief efforts.\n\nThe Florida National Guard has 3,000 service members set for the response efforts along Florida State Guard, Florida Department of Law Enforcement, Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission and county emergency response personnel with an arsenal of high-water vehicles and other response equipment.\n\nIt's the fourth hurricane to hit Florida in August since 2000 following Hurricane Charley in 2004, Katrina in 2005 and last year's Hurricane Idalia.\n\nFDEM Director Kevin Guthrie said some places saw 10 to 12 inches in southwest Florida with rivers and streams expected to go into flood stage this week, especially in North Florida where the storm continues to dump torrents of rain on the area.\n\n\"This is going to be an event that is going to be probably here for the next five to seven days, maybe as long as 10 days depending on how much rainfall we get, so we are not running anywhere,\" he said. \"We are staying put and we're going to make sure that we're here to respond.\"\n\nIn an effort to stem any post-storm deaths and injuries, he urged those with damage on their homes to not to try and take care of it themselves.\n\n\"Please do not get up on a ladder. Do not try to put a tarp on a roof. Do not try to cut a limb. We have volunteer organizations that will come and help you with that,\" Guthrie said asking people instead contact their local emergency management agency. \"We will make sure somebody comes and helps you on your property. Do not risk yourself, do not risk injury. We will come and help you.\"\n\nStorm surge was forecast to raise water levels from 6 to 10 feet on parts of Big Bend closest to the storm's center. A tide station in Cedar Key on Monday morning recorded water level at 4.6 feet above normal, the NHC reported.\n\nThe tropical storm and storm surge warnings had ceased for Florida's west coast as of 5 p.m.\n\nA tropical storm warning remains in effect on the east coast from Georgia and South Carolina coast from the mouth of the St. Mary's River to South Santee River in South Carolina; South Carolina and North Carolina coast from north of South Santee River to Cape Fear, North Carolina; St. Augustine, Florida to South Santee River, South Carolina; and north of South Santee River, South Carolina to Cape Fear, North Carolina.\n\n\"A turn toward the east is expected on Tuesday, followed by a turn to the north at a slow forward speed on Wednesday,\" said NHC senior hurricane specialist Daniel Brown. \"On the forecast track, the center will move across southeastern Georgia tonight and Tuesday, move offshore of the South Carolina coast by late Tuesday and Wednesday, and approach the South Carolina coast on Thursday.\"\n\nAs of 8 p.m., about 160,000 customers were without power in Florida, down from a high of more than 300,000 on Monday morning, while more than 26,000 customers were without power in Georgia, according to poweroutage.us, About 11,000 remain without power in Pinellas County, which was lashed all day Sunday by bands from the storm. In Central Florida, less than 100 were without power in Lake County down from more than 20,000 on Monday morning.\n\nDeSantis said power issues are not as bad as Idalia and nowhere near what was seen with 2022's Hurricane Ian.\n\n\"We have a lot of restoration personnel ready to go to get it back on,\" he said. \"We do have 17,000 linemen that are ready to assist with restoring power immediately and I know a lot of the utilities have already restored hundreds of thousands of folks starting yesterday.\"\n\nThe system had grown since becoming Tropical Depression Four late Friday and developing into a tropical storm on Saturday.\n\nThe NHC expects rainfall from 6 to 12 inches with some areas getting up to 18 inches across portions of Florida, and up to 30 inches across parts of the Southeast U.S. this weekend and through Thursday morning that could cause flash and urban flooding as well as some isolated river flooding.\n\n\"This potentially historic rainfall will likely result in areas of catastrophic flooding,\" NHC forecasters said.\n\nThe NHC also continues to track a system in the Caribbean with a chance to form into the season's next tropical depression or storm.\n\nAs of the NHC's 8 p.m. tropical outlook Monday, the tropical wave was located near the Caribbean's Windward Islands with disorganized showers and thunderstorms.\n\n\"Any development of this system should be slow to occur during the next couple of days while it moves westward over the eastern and central Caribbean Sea,\" forecasters said. \"Environmental conditions are expected to become more conducive for development later this week as the system moves across the western Caribbean Sea or the southern Gulf of Mexico.\"\n\nThe NHC gives it a 10% chance to develop in the next two days and 30% in the next seven days.\n\nIf it were to form into a named storm, it could take on the name Tropical Storm Ernesto.\n\nDebby became the fourth official system of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season. The others were Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris.\n\nHurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30, but the height of storm formation runs from mid-August into {"uri": "8261005358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "02:39:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T02:39:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T02:38:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/the-latest-debby-blamed-for-multiple-deaths-in-florida-georgia-leaves-thousands-without-power/article_67e107c9-764b-56c8-a5bd-a5dc31f01a90.html", "title": "The Latest: Debby blamed for multiple deaths in Florida, Georgia, leaves thousands without power", "body": "Savannah resident Roi Roizaken loads sandbags into his van as rain from Hurricane Debby starts to fall, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, in Savannah, Ga. Forecasters warned heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.\n\nBy The Associated Press\n\nHigh winds and heavy rains from Tropical Storm Debby lashed Florida on Monday. At least four deaths were reported in the state, and hundreds had to be rescued from flooded homes.\n\nThe storm is now threatening to flood some of America's most historic Southern cities.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nHundreds rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, area, officials say\n\nAbout 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, Florida, a beach city popular with tourists, the Sarasota Police Department said Monday in a social media post.\n\n\"Essentially we've had twice the amount of the rain that was predicted for us to have,\" Sarasota County Fire Chief David Rathbun said in a social media update.\n\nPeople are also reading... VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Platter & Pour working to open State Street location Badcock Furniture closing all its retail locations HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment PRO GOLF: Runner-up for Connor Creasy (Abingdon) in PGA Americas Tour tourney in Ottawa HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon\n\nJust north of Sarasota, officials in Manatee County said in a news release that 186 people were rescued from flood waters.\n\n\"We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,\" said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director. \"The safety of our residents is our top priority, and we are doing everything in our power to respond effectively to this crisis.\"\n\nMan killed when storm topples large tree onto home in south Georgia, officials say\n\nHeavy winds and rain associated with Debby toppled a large tree onto a porch at a home in south Georgia, killing a 19-year-old man, authorities said Monday.\n\nColquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock said the man died at the home in the city of Moultrie, about 40 miles (64 kilometers) northwest of Valdosta, Georgia, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.\n\nThe storm has damaged roofs and downed power lines in Moultrie, Police Chief Chad Castleberry told WALB-TV.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Debby had top winds near 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening as it moved slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns eastward.\n\nCharleston, South Carolina, announces curfew, roads into historic city to be closed\n\nCharleston, South Carolina, officials announced a curfew starting at 11 p.m. Monday for the peninsula that makes up much of downtown and the older parts of the 350-year-old city as some of the heaviest rain from Tropical Storm Debby is expected to fall overnight.\n\nPolice will barricade all eight roads leading into the peninsula and only let essential workers and emergency personnel in or out. High-water vehicles will also be staged to go into the area as needed, Charleston Mayor William Cogswell said at a Monday evening news conference.\n\n\"We need people to make their way out. This is not something you can stay at the bar until 10:45. We need you to take this seriously,\" Cogswell said.\n\nThe mayor said forecasters told him 10 to 12 inches (25 to 30 centimeters) of rain could fall in Charleston overnight.\n\nCity officials will assess the situation early Tuesday and decide how and when to reopen roads and lift the curfew.\n\nNo evacuations planned for now in South Carolina, officials say\n\nState officials don't plan any evacuations in South Carolina for now as Tropical Storm Debby slowly spins toward the state.\n\nLarge-scale evacuations typically bring people inland from the coast, and forecasters say Debby's biggest impacts could be as much as 30 inches (76 centimeters) of rain in localized areas throughout the state, causing floodwaters to rise quickly in small areas. So any evacuations will up to local leaders.\n\n\"This storm may not have the high winds of a hurricane, but it has the potential to cause life-threatening floods across the state. And I would like to emphasize that Tropical Storm Debby is not just a coastal event, but it is a statewide event,\" state Emergency Management Division Director Kim Stenson said at a Monday afternoon news conference.\n\nBiden approves request from South Carolina's governor for emergency declaration\n\nThe White House said Monday that President Joe Biden has approved a request from South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster for an emergency declaration, following his earlier approval of a similar request from Florida.\n\nIn a statement, the White House said personnel from the Department of Defense, the Department of Homeland Security, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the U.S. Coast Guard are deploying to the region and are prepared to support recovery efforts.\n\nNorth Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency Monday ahead of Debby's anticipated rainfall. Flooding and power outages are expected to start Tuesday and continue through the rest of the week, according to North Carolina Emergency Management officials.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis previously had declared a state of emergency for 61 of Florida's 67 counties, with the National Guard activating 3,000 guard members. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp also had made his own emergency declaration.\n\nCurfew announced for Savannah and surrounding county as Debby approaches\n\nWith Debby's winds and rains expected to worsen overnight, officials for Savannah and surrounding Chatham County announced that an overnight curfew will take effect at 10 p.m. Monday and run to 6 a.m. Tuesday. The National Hurricane Center says the region can expect rains that could exceed 20 inches (51 centimeters).\n\nBy Monday afternoon, the storm's outer bands were lashing Tybee Island, home to Georgia's largest public beach, blowing sheets of rain sideways and rattling street signs near the beach pier. The island of 3,100 residents east of Savannah was bracing for a potential double-dose of flooding from an expected 2 to 4 feet of storm surge on top of rainfall.\n\n\"This is unprecedented rainfall,\" said Michelle Owens, Tybee Island's interim city manager. She added: \"We don't know what that looks like. So we have to be prepared for the worst. But we are definitely hoping for the best.\"\n\nPublic works crews used earthmoving equipment to heap sand over beach access points to help fortify a storm surge buffer offered by surrounding dunes. Owens said the city also had given out about 2,000 sandbags to island residents.\n\nAngela Thompson had several sandbags ready by the front door of her ground-level apartment near Tybee Creek on the island's west side. She had just started moving in earlier this week and hoped to ride out the storm while unpacking.\n\n\"I have food and water and batteries and the things that I need, and I'm going to stay as long as I can,\" Thompson said.\n\nFlorida will be on alert for flooding for the next week, Gov. Ron DeSantis says\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis warned that just because Tropical Storm Debby is moving toward Georgia, that doesn't mean the state won't continue to see threats as waterways north of the border fill up and flow south.\n\n\"It is a very saturating, wet storm,\" DeSantis said during a briefing at the state's emergency operations center. \"When they crest and the water that's going to come down from Georgia, it's just something that we're going to be on alert for not just throughout today, but for the next week.\"\n\nRecord-setting rain was forecast to cause flash flooding in coastal Georgia and South Carolina and into North Carolina, with up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) of rainfall in some areas, according to the National Hurricane Center. Debby made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over Florida's gulf coast. The storm was moving slowly to the north-northeast and was expected to slow down as it turns to the east.\n\nNo deaths or injuries in Florida county where Debby made landfall, sheriff says\n\nThe sheriff of Florida's Taylor County, where Debby came ashore as a hurricane Monday, says there are no deaths or injuries in the sparsely populated area located in the state's northern Big Bend region.\n\nBut Sheriff Wayne Padgett advised anyone who had evacuated from low-lying and coastal areas to wait before returning because the tide will be coming in and it's unknown how deep the water might get. Several roads are closed due to flooding as well as trees and power lines downed by the storm, Padgett said.\n\nDebby made landfall as a category 1 hurricane near Steinhatchee, a tiny community of less than 1,000 residents.\n\nMayor warns tourists, residents on South Carolina's Hilton Head Island: Don't let your guard down\n\nNo evacuations were planned Monday on South Carolina's Hilton Head Island, one of the state's most popular beach destinations. But Mayor Alan Perry warned tourists and residents not to let their guard down with forecasts predicting up to 30 inches (76 centimeters) of rain this week from Debby.\n\n\"We don't know how much rain is going to fall. But we have to prepare for the worst,\" Perry said. \"If that happens, we will see an event we have never seen on Hilton Head before.\"\n\nIn a video posted on Facebook, Perry asked island residents and visitors to check on each other before the heavy rain starts -- and maybe help the city out by checking storm drains. \"If you are able to go out and pull some debris from those drains so they can drain, that's is really key to preventing additional flooding,\" he said.\n\nHilton Head Island has about 38,000 residents. Officials estimate up to 250,000 tourists can be on the island on the busiest summer days.\n\nIn saturated Savannah, residents prepare for potentially historic rains\n\nAs Debby threatened to dump potentially historic flooding rains across southeast Georgia, more than 20 people in Savannah filled sandbags at a park in the city's suburban southside. Rain soaked their clothes and mud stuck to their shoes. Officials are especially concerned about Debby because the area already is saturated after Savannah recorded 8.5 inches of rain in July, 3 inches greater than normal, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nJim Froncak tossed a dozen full bags into the back of his pickup truck while his son and a friend did the shoveling. Even though his home sits about 2 feet off the ground, Froncak said he won't be surprised if a nearby ditch overflows with floodwaters capable of reaching his doors.\n\n\"A really heavy thunderstorm will fill it up,\" Froncak said. \"So whatever's coming is really going to fill it up and flow over.\"\n\nCity crews spent days ahead of Debby's arrival clearing storm drains throughout Savannah. Some low-lying neighborhoods outside the historic downtown area had flooded streets from thunderstorms less than two weeks ago.\n\nPackages containing cocaine wash up on beach in Florida Keys during storm, Border Patrol says\n\nIn the Florida Keys, Debby blew packages containing 70 pounds (32 kilograms) of cocaine onto a beach, the U.S. Border Patrol's Miami sector reported Monday.\n\nA \"good Samaritan\" found the drugs and contacted authorities, the agency said. The cocaine has a street value of more than $1 million, the agency said on social media. It's didn't say exactly where the cocaine was found.\n\nVice President Harris postpones trip to Georgia\n\nVice President Kamala Harris is postponing a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby.\n\nHarris' campaign said her stop planned in Savannah, Georgia, on Thursday, was being put off due to the storm.\n\nHarris is choosing her running mate and will introduce the choice during a rally in Philadelphia on Tuesday. The pair will then travel together starting on Wednesday to a series of key battleground states: Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Arizona and Nevada. But the Georgia leg of the original journey has been canceled for now.\n\nDebby made landfall in Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and was expected to bring potentially record-setting rainfall to Georgia and South Carolina as it heads east.\n\nDebby forces flight cancellations at Florida airports\n\nMore than 1,600 flights were canceled nationwide by midday Monday, many of them to and from Florida airports, according to FlightAware.com. One out of every five flights scheduled to leave Orlando International Airport was canceled Monday, with just as many incoming flights canceled there.\n\nNearly 30 percent of flights scheduled to depart Tampa International Airport on Monday were canceled. High numbers of canceled flights were also reported at airports in Jacksonville and Fort Myers.\n\nBiden briefed on Debby's progress\n\nPresident Joe Biden was briefed on Debby's progress while at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, the White House said Monday.\n\nThe White House said Biden on Saturday approved Florida's request for an emergency declaration and that federal rescue personnel, meals and water have been deployed to the storm-stricken region. The administration is closely monitoring the storm and response effort with state and local officials, it said.\n\nA 13-year-old boy dies when tree falls on mobile home in Florida, and officials report other deaths in storm\n\nA 13-year-old boy died Monday morning after a tree fell on a mobile home located southwest of Gainesville, Florida, according to the Levy County Sheriff's Office.\n\nOfficials reported other deaths as Debby moved inland.\n\nA truck driver died early Monday on Interstate 75 in the Tampa area after he lost control of his tractor trailer, which flipped over a concrete wall and dangled over water before the cab dropped into the water below.\n\nEast of Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida near where the storm made landfall, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy were killed late Sunday when the car she was driving on a wet road struck a median and then overturned off the road. A 14-year-old boy who was a passenger was hospitalized with serious injuries, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.\n\nDebby weakens to a tropical storm but flooding threat continues\n\nDebby has weakened into a tropical storm with top winds hovering around 45 mph (75 kph) Monday evening. The National Hurricane Center in Miami said the storm was moving slowly to the northeast. It was expected to cross southeastern Georgia and to slow to a crawl as it turns to the east. Debby made landfall as a hurricane in the Big Bend region of Florida, one of the state's least populated areas.\n\nForecasters are still warning that heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia. Substantial rainfall was expected as well in central and northeast North Carolina through Wednesday morning.\n\nBig worry is storm surge from Debby\n\nForecasters said storm surge was expected to be the biggest threat for Florida, with 6 to 10 feet (1.8 to 3 meters) of inundation above ground level predicted in part of the zone near the Big Bend.\n\n\"That part of the coast is a very vulnerable spot,\" John Cangialosi, a hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center, said Monday. Some areas, including Sarasota and Manatee counties, have already received 10 to 12 inches (25 to 30 centimeters) of rain.\n\nIn Georgia, the National Weather Service is predicting major flooding on some rivers: the Canoochee River near Claxton, the Ohoopee River near Reidsville and the Ogeechee River near Eden. All those rivers were below flood stage Monday but could see their water levels more than double by later in the week.\n\nHundreds of thousands without power\n\nMore than 300,000 customers were without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis said some 17,000 linemen are working to restore electricity. He warned residents in affected areas to sit tight until conditions are safe.\n\n\"When the water rises, when you have streets that can be flooded, that's hazardous,\" DeSantis said. \"Don't try to drive through this. We don't want to see traffic fatalities adding up. Don't tempt fate, don't try to go through these flooded streets.\"\n\n-- -\n\nThis version corrects the attribution for power outage figures to PowerOutage.us, not PowerOutage.com.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8261674174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:15:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:15:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:14:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/marshallshepherd/2024/08/06/3-reasons-tropical-storm-debby-is-producing-so-much-rain/", "title": "3 Reasons Tropical Storm Debby Is Producing So Much Rain", "body": "Hurricane Debby made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 storm. It caused storm surge risks, tornadoes, and wind damage across much of Florida on Sunday and Monday. However, the hazard that I have consistently focused on with Debby is the potential for extreme rainfall. At the time of writing early Tuesday morning, a dangerous rainfall threat persists for coastal Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina through the end of the work week. Here are three reasons why Tropical Storm Debby is causing such extreme rainfall.\n\nA Reservoir Of Moisture Availability\n\nTropical Storm Debby has a reservoir of moisture available to it. Parts of Florida have received over 15 inches of rainfall from the storm, and there is more to come in the Southeast. To have this part of the conversation, I introduce you to precipitable water or PWAT. It is variable that we use to assess the amount of water available to weather systems. It is formally defined in the NOAA Glossary as, \"The depth of liquid water at the surface that would result after precipitating all of the water vapor in a vertical column over a given location, usually extending from the surface to 300 mb.\" With that context, let's dissect what Ben Noll says in his post below. Noll, a meteorologist with the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research in New Zealand, points out the extreme values of PWAT available to Debby.\n\nNoll said, \"It (PWAT)is very useful toward ultimately understanding how much rain may fall from the sky.... 2 inches are generally considered high; however, with Debby, amounts are expected to exceed 3 inches and even push *4 inches* in some states.\"\n\nExtremely Warm Water\n\nWhy are the PWAT values so high? The water temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico and the western Atlantic are particularly high. The combination of warming climate and the El Nino that dissipated recently left the Gulf of Mexico and other water bodies particularly warm in the Atlantic Basin. Sea surface temperatures in waters that Debby traversed in recent days have been running one to four degrees above normal for this time of year, and this is typically when we expect, from a seasonal perspective, \"hotter\" water.\n\nBasic physics explains why warmer water evaporates faster. A University of Illinois website notes, \"It's true that the rate at which the water molecules leaves goes up quickly as the water gets hotter.... So, the evaporation is much faster when the water is hotter.\" The energy source for hurricanes is latent heat of water. The evaporation provides a source of water vapor that ultimately condenses in the storm. When condensation happens, \"energy\" is released to the storm. A University of Arizona lecture website says, \"Condensing a gram of water vapor to liquid at normal temperatures releases about 60% of the energy that detonating a gram of TNT would.\"\n\nAndrew Dessler is a professor at Texas A&M University. In a May blog entry countering climate misinformation, he reminds readers, \"You don't need any fancy physics to understand why we're so confident that tropical cyclones will produce more rain as the climate warms.... the IPCC says that we are already seeing this.\" He goes on to include statements from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report noting high confidence that climate change contributed to storms like Harvey (2017) and that the rate that rain falls is increasing.\n\nA Slow-moving System\n\nMost storms make landfall and move out. Like Tropical Storm Allison (2001), Hurricane Harvey (2017), and Hurricane Florence (2018), Debby is slow-moving and is even likely to stall for the next couple of days. Why so? Well, it is not a rock and a hard place, but two high pressure areas bookend the storm to the west and northeast, respectively. Debby is kind of stuck with a lack of guidance until the wind pattern changes by the end of the week. For this reason, parts of coastal Georgia and the Carolinas are facing potentially historic flooding. All week, I have focused on the rainfall threat with this storm. Unfortunately, when people hear \"hurricane,\" the category or wind speeds often shape the narrative. Debby will be remembered (and its name likely retired) because of rainfall.\n\nAs of Tuesday morning, the National Hurricane Center writes, \"The center is likely to move offshore the Georgia coast later today, but then meander off the coast of South Carolina through early Thursday.\" Strengthening could happen if it moves back over water. By the weekend, Debby will move into the Mid-Atlantic region bringing the \"firehose\" of moisture with it. NOAA forecasters emphasize, \"Potentially historic heavy rainfall across southeast Georgia and eastern South Carolina through Friday will likely result in areas of catastrophic flooding. Heavy rainfall will likely result in flooding impacts from northern North Carolina through portions of Mid-Atlantic States and southern New England through Sunday morning.\"\n\nIn 2018, my University of Georgia colleague Pam Knox wrote, \"Long-time residents of Georgia may remember the devastating floods of Tropical Storm Alberto in July 1994.... rain was so intense that Georgia's one-day rainfall record was set during that storm, with 21.10 inches recorded at Americus for a 24-hour period ending on July 6, 1994, as the storm stalled over the state.\" Sound familiar? In 2007, some of my scholarly work revealed that tropical storms and \"weaker\" hurricanes are often more prolific rainfall-producers. Debby will be no different.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_weather", "type": The driver was found dead.\n\nIn Dixie County, just west of Gainesville, officials reported that a woman and a 12-year-old were killed when their car crashed on Sunday night.\n\nIn southern Georgia, another death - a 19-year-old - was reported after a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, local media reported.\n\nThe slow-moving pace of the storm could bring \"catastrophic flooding\", Jamie Rhome, the deputy director of the hurricane centre, said.\n\nDebby's waves and strong winds helped blow 25 packages of cocaine, worth more than $1m, ashore in the Florida Keys, according to the US Border Patrol.\n\nIn Florida, some 150,000 homes and businesses were without power on Monday night, according to PowerOutage.com. Another 36,000 residents in Georgia and South Carolina were experiencing outages.\n\nThe storm is forecast to skim the coast, drenching south-east Georgia and the Carolinas on Tuesday and Wednesday, before moving inland near the South Carolina coast on Thursday.\n\nBefore the storm made landfall, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 61 of Florida's 67 counties.\n\nSpyridon Aibejeris told USA Today repairs on his Keaton Beach home had just wrapped up two weeks ago from Hurricane Idalia, a category three storm that made landfall last summer.\n\n\"Man, I've done this so many times,\" Mr Aibejeris said.\n\nForecasters predicted this hurricane season, which runs from 1 June to 30 November, would be a busy one.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (Noaa) said there could be up to 25 named storms in 2024.\n\nBetween eight and 13 of those storms could develop into hurricanes.\n\nDebby was the fourth named storm of the year.\n\nIt is thought that climate change may be making slow-moving hurricanes like this more likely.\n\nAs the world heats unevenly, this causes changes in the atmospheric circulations that {"uri": "2024-08-444975722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:42:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:42:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:28:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/tropical-storm-debby-causes-4-deaths-in-florida-and-leaves-250000-without-power/", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby causes 4 deaths in Florida and leaves 250,000 without power - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Governor Ron DeSantis announced that Tropical Storm Debby has sadly claimed four lives on Monday. The fatalities include a tragic double-car accident in Dixie County, a fatality in a truck crash in Hillsborough County, and a young boy who lost his life when a tree fell on his family's home in Levy County.\n\nTropical Storm Debby hit land at approximately 7 a.m. on Monday near Steinhatchee as a Category 1 storm, marking the Big Bend region's second hurricane within a year.\n\nWith initial maximum winds of 80 mph, Debby weakened to a tropical storm, changed direction to the northeast, and then proceeded to move erratically across North Florida and Southeast Georgia. The National Hurricane Center warned of the potential for \"catastrophic flooding in some areas.\"\n\n\"We have seen and will continue to see flooding in every part of the state of Florida,\" Gov. Ron DeSantis said during a morning news conference at the state Emergency Operations Center.\n\nDeSantis said as of Monday afternoon, 250,000 customers were without power across the state and over 450,000 accounts have been restored since the storm began.\n\nThe Florida Division of Emergency Management has completed 435 storm-related missions, and they are currently in the process of completing another 400 more, DeSantis said.\n\nDeSantis said the state is ready to make more flooding rescues after the storm passes as waters rise.\n\nHe said Tampa and St. Petersburg ports are closed but are due to open Monday evening and all airports are open.\n\nThe storm is expected to move off the southeast U.S. coast late Tuesday and could come back inland over South Carolina on Thursday.\n\nSteinhatchee is in Taylor County, roughly 90 miles south of Tallahassee. On Aug. 30, 2023, Hurricane Idalia made landfall in Taylor County's Keaton Beach with maximum sustained winds of 125 mph and storm surge of 7 to 12 feet along the coast. Idalia then caused widespread damage as it moved across North Florida.\n\nDeSantis said Debby won't be as devastating, but huge risks remain.\n\nDebby, potentially a historic rainmaker, started pounding the Gulf Coast on Sunday.\n\nState Division of Emergency Management Director Kevin Guthrie said the goal is to restore electricity to 80 to 85 percent of customers within 24 to 48 hours.\n\n\"We're going to tackle it,\" he said. \"It's going to be all hands on deck going in there to get that power restored.\"\n\nGuthrie said more than 35 tornado warnings had been issued in the state, and additional \"tornadic activity\" will occur as the system moves across North Florida.\n\n\"The hazards from this storm will be seen and felt far outside the center of the cone,\" Guthrie said, referring to the cone showing the storm's potential path. \"Flood impacts are going to be felt everywhere.\"\n\nNorth Florida and Central Florida could get 10 to 12 inches of rain, which will cause rivers to flood during the next week, Guthrie said.\n\nPart of recovery efforts will include moving resources closer to the Sarasota Bradenton area, which DeSantis said received \"a significant amount of water.\"\n\nDeSantis said he didn't anticipate the state will \"dent\" the more than 11 million bottles of water and 3 million meal rations available.\n\nOn Sunday, the White House said President Joe Biden had approved a federal emergency declaration to provide assistance. The declaration authorizes the Federal Emergency Management Agency to coordinate disaster relief efforts and cover 75 percent of certain storm costs for counties.", "source": {"uri": Storm Debby travel advice as nearly 2,000 US flights cancelled", "body": "Hurricane Debby was announced to make landfall at 7am on Monday (August 5), bringing with it risks of flooding, dangerous storm surge, and power outages.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center in the US confirmed winds as high as 80mph, making it a Category 1 storm.\n\nIt has since been downgraded to a tropical storm, with six deaths confirmed so far. That includes a 12-year-old girl and a 13-year-old boy in Levy County after a tree fell and a 19-year-old man near Valdosta, Georgia, who died when a tree fell onto a porch.\n\nOthers killed include an 18-wheeler truck driver who lost control of the vehicle on Interstate 75, and a 38-year-old woman and her 12-year-old son whose SUV crashed during stormy weather in Tampa.\n\nDebby is continuing to move across Florida, with forecasts expected to hit South Carolina on Wednesday and continuing throughout the week before starting to settle down.\n\nHere's a look at whether it's safe to travel to Florida amidst the hurricane.\n\nWhile travel is technically allowed to Florida, nearly 2,000 flights were canceled in the US on August 5, according to flight tracking website FlightAware.\n\nFloridian airports all reported significant numbers of flight cancellations and delays.\n\nThese disruptions could mean it's likely wise to cancel or change plans to travel to Florida until the storm has passed to avoid getting stranded. This also includes those who might have connecting flights through Florida to get to other locations.\n\nAccording to official advice from Visit Florida, the storm is expected to make \"a turn toward the east\" today, \"followed by a turn to the north at a slow forward speed on Wednesday\".\n\n\"On the forecast track, the center will move across southeastern Georgia tonight and Tuesday, move offshore of the South Carolina coast by late Tuesday and Wednesday, and approach the South Carolina coast on Thursday,\" the statement reads.\n\nStorm Debby is expected to last at least until {"uri": "8260681672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:06:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:06:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.terradaily.com/afp/240805193431.82f4dn06.html", "title": "US braces for 'catastrophic' flooding as Storm Debby drenches Florida", "body": "A 13-year-old boy died when a tree was blown onto a mobile home in Levy County, the sheriff's office there said, after Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast earlier in the day as a Category One hurricane.\n\nThe Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office said it had pulled out a semi-truck along with its deceased driver after it toppled into a bypass canal off I-75, while a 38-year-old woman and 12-year-old boy from Crawfordville were killed during a crash in bad weather on Sunday night, the Florida Highway Patrol said.\n\nA 14-year-old boy survived the crash with serious injuries.\n\nAuthorities say the danger remains high as the storm moves over the state and into Georgia and South Carolina, despite the downgrade by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) from hurricane back down to tropical storm.\n\n\"This is a level four out of four risk for excessive rainfall,\" Michael Brennan, director of the NHC, told reporters.\n\n\"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina,\" he added.\n\nFlorida Governor Ron DeSantis also warned of \"significant\" flooding over the coming days, and said the state had already seen storm surge and some water rising.\n\nAround 275,000 customers in Florida and Georgia have lost electricity so far, according to tracker poweroutage.us.\n\n\"We have a lot of restoration personnel ready to go to get it back on,\" DeSantis said.\n\nThe NHC warned of life-threatening storm surges along the Gulf coast, with up to five feet (1.5 meters) of inundation above ground level in some areas.\n\nBy early afternoon, the storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 65 mph (100 kph) as it swept over northern Florida. Storm surge warnings are in effect in parts of the three states, indicating \"life-threatening inundation, from rising water moving inland from the coastline.\"\n\nThe storm will probably cause catastrophic flooding with \"potentially historic heavy rainfall\" when Debby moves northeast across Georgia and South Carolina over the next few days, the NHC said.\n\nBut it said Debby was weakening. The storm's maximum sustained winds were 80 miles (130 kilometers) per hour at landfall but dropped to 65 mph at the 2:00 pm ET (1800 GMT) update.\n\nDebby is expected to dump up to 18 inches of rainfall in parts of Florida, and as much as 30 inches in coastal Georgia, South Carolina, and parts of North Carolina before the week is over, the NHC said.\n\nMandatory evacuations were ordered for part of Citrus County, Florida, with eight other counties under voluntary evacuation orders, local media reported.\n\nThe governors of Georgia and South Carolina declared a state of emergency ahead of the storm's arrival.\n\nPresident Joe Biden on Sunday approved an emergency declaration for Florida, allowing federal aid to be expedited.\n\nDeSantis has activated the state's National Guard, with {"uri": "8261720823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:49:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:49:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:44:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/days-devastation-expected-deadly-tropical-113517964.html", "title": "Days of Devastation Expected From Deadly Tropical Storm Debby", "body": "At least five people were killed after Debby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday, with forecasters warning that several more days of devastation are to come.\n\nAfter hundreds of people were rescued from flooded homes in Florida, meteorologists said Tuesday morning that other states will face a similar deluge. \"Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday,\" the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nHurricane Debby Makes Landfall, Bringing 'Potentially Historic' Flooding\n\nAs of 5 a.m. ET, Debby was inland over southeastern Georgia moving northeast. The center of the storm is \"expected to move offshore the coast of Georgia later today, drift offshore through early Thursday, and then move inland over South Carolina on Thursday,\" according to the hurricane center.\n\nAt least four deaths in Florida have been linked to Debby, which made landfall in the state's Big Bend coast on Monday morning.\n\nOn Sunday night, a 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy were killed in a car crash in Dixie County, with witnesses saying the car lost control due to the wet road and inclement road, according WJXT-TV. {"uri": "8261284378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "07:04:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T07:04:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T07:03:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://nybreaking.com/horrifying-pictures-show-the-devastating-impact-from-hurricane-debby-as-it-rips-across-the-south-heres-where-its-yet-to-strike/", "title": "Horrifying Pictures Show The Devastating Impact From Hurricane Debby As It Rips Across The South - Here's Where It's Yet To Strike - Ny Breaking News", "body": "Shocking footage shows the devastating impact of Hurricane Debby after the storm made landfall in Big Bend, Florida.\n\nHeavy rainfall has so far caused significant damage and killed at least five people, two of them children.\n\nThe center of Debby is located about 60 miles (96 kilometers) north-northwest of Jacksonville, Florida. Experts expect the tropical storm to produce historic amounts of rain and cause catastrophic flooding from northern Florida to southeastern North Carolina overnight Friday into Saturday.\n\nAlthough maximum sustained winds have now slowed to about 45 mph (72 kph), the storm has devastated much of Florida's Gulf Coast, downing power lines, flooding streets and toppling trees.\n\nCharleston could see more than two feet of rain over the next five days, while Savannah could see its typical summer-long rainfall in the same period, prompting both cities to be placed under mandatory curfews.\n\nThe latest hurricane forecasts indicate that South Carolina could be hit as early as 2:00 p.m. ET on Thursday\n\nDebby's slow movement over land could bring 10 to 30 inches (25 to 75 centimeters) of rainfall to some areas, likely worsening the storm and causing further damage to roads, bridges and other key infrastructure.\n\nThe storm is expected to move slowly eastward through Georgia and then into the Atlantic on Tuesday. Debby will turn north and strengthen on Wednesday before making landfall in South Carolina on Thursday evening.\n\nNorth Carolina will also be affected, with the storm expected to arrive there sometime on Friday.\n\nWhile the storm largely passes Florida, more than 133,000 customers were still without power as of 1 a.m. ET, according to the state. poweroutage.us.\n\nIn Georgia, that number is over 28,000. That number is likely to rise as the wind and rain intensify through Tuesday morning.\n\nAll this comes as authorities release the latest death toll from the devastating storm: five people have died so far, four in Florida and one in Georgia.\n\nA 19-year-old died Monday afternoon in Moultrie, Georgia after a tree fell on the side of a home, the latest fatality.\n\nMoultrie is located in southern Georgia, approximately 200 miles south of Atlanta.\n\nA similar tragedy occurred in Levy County, Florida, where a 13-year-old boy was crushed to death by a tree that fell on his mobile home, the first life lost to the storm.\n\nThe second fatality occurred early Monday morning in a tractor-trailer near Tampa. The 64-year-old Mississippi man lost control on the icy road and plunged off a freeway bridge into a canal, the Florida Highway Patrol said.\n\nPictured: A tree fell on the home of a 13-year-old boy. The trunk fatally crushed him. He was the first to lose his life to the hurricane\n\nHillsborough County Fire Rescue is pictured pulling a truck out of the water after it went off the road in the early morning hours of Monday\n\nTragically, the driver of the truck did not survive the fall\n\n\"The vehicle spun, struck a concrete guardrail on the outside of the shoulder and went over the wall,\" the highway patrol wrote in a news release after the incident.\n\n\"The trailer came to rest hanging from the bridge, with the cab separating and landing in the Tampa Bypass Canal.\"\n\nHeartbreaking photos show members of the Hillsborough County Fire Rescue team in Florida pulling the truck out of the water.\n\nA 38-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy were also killed in a car crash in Dixie County, Florida, on Sunday evening.\n\nA 14-year-old boy who was also in the car is in critical condition, CNN reported.\n\nWitnesses to the single-vehicle crash told police the car lost control and \"hit the guardrail in the median strip, then changed direction, overturned and left the right-hand lane,\" the highway patrol statement said.\n\nAccording to police, none of the three people were wearing a seat belt.\n\nPolice and emergency workers sail boats through once passable streets to rescue people from flooded homes\n\nA member of the Sarasota Sheriff's Department is seen wading in water higher than his waist\n\nIn Gulfport, a city near Tampa, a man's body was found by police after witnesses said he had anchored his sailboat near Gulfport's Veteran's Park. FOX 13 reported.\n\nThe man's identity has not yet been established, but it is believed to be 48-year-old Brian Clough who is on the boat.\n\nClough reportedly lives on his boat with his dog, who was rescued by nearby boaters.\n\nFurther south, in Sarasota, Florida, police and emergency workers raced through flooded streets and successfully evacuated about 500 people from submerged homes.\n\nThe city, located about 60 miles (96 kilometers) from Tampa, received more than a foot (30 centimeters) of rain from the storm, enough to last more than a month.\n\nThe extreme flooding in Debby also caused damage to critical infrastructure across the state.\n\nAn example of this can be found in southern Hillsborough County, near Tampa, where a 15-foot stretch of road completely collapsed after a dormant sinkhole was ripped open by flowing water.\n\nOn Monday, officials closed the road to traffic.\n\nBrian Clough, another suspected victim of the deadly tropical storm, is pictured next to his dog\n\nA 15-foot stretch of road in southern Hillsborough County, near Tampa, completely collapsed as a dormant sinkhole was ripped open by rushing water\n\nSailboats docked in Tampa Bay are pictured unmoored and crashing into the seawall.\n\nA truck lies overturned on Independence Parkway in Tampa\n\nMeanwhile, this family decided to take their ATV for a spin, testing it out on the now completely flooded streets of eastern Hillsborough County\n\nAs Debby moves slowly over land, some areas could drop 10 to 30 inches of rain, potentially causing further damage to roads, bridges, and other critical infrastructure.\n\nAs the situation in the south worsens, governors are taking their response strategies seriously.\n\nGeorgia Governor Brian Kemp has deployed 2,000 National Guard members to assist with evacuations and rescue efforts.\n\nRoy Cooper, the governor of North Carolina, a state that has not yet been hit, has declared a preemptive state of emergency.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has also declared states of emergency in Florida, Georgia and North Carolina, a move that will mobilize emergency aid.", "source": {"uri": "nybreaking.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NY Breaking
