{"uri": "8261743706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:00:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:00:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:59:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tornado-watch-issued-wilmington-area-112619808.html", "title": "Tornado watch issued for the Wilmington area ahead of Tropical Storm Debby's arrival", "body": "A tornado watch has been issued for Southeastern North Carolina until 5 p.m. Tuesday. A watch means that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours.\n\nAs of 5 a.m. Tuesday, Tropical Storm Debby was churning over Georgia. It's expected to move offshore today, with a significant risk of flash flooding over Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina during the next few days, the National Hurricane Center reported.\n\nMeanwhile, a tropical storm watch is in effect for the North Carolina coast up to Surf City. And a storm surge watch has been issued for the Brunswick County coast.\n\n\"This is a life-threatening situation. Persons located within these areas should take all necessary actions to protect life and property from rising water and the potential for other dangerous conditions,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nOn Monday, Debby made landfall near the coastal town of Steinhatchee, Florida. It's the fourth named storm of the hurricane season and arrived with sustained winds of 80 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nMore: Flooding hotspots to watch for in the Wilmington area with historic rainfall predicted\n\nSTORM TRACKER: Monitor the latest tropical developments here.\n\nHere's a look at what we can expect in the Wilmington area, according to the latest briefing from the National Weather Service in Wilmington.\n\nThe most likely time of arrival of strong winds to the Wilmington area is Thursday morning. The probability of tropical storm force winds continues to increase, especially along coastal areas from Cape Fear southward.\n\nBrunswick, New Hanover and Pender counties are expected to see rainfall amounts of 12 to 16 inches, which could result in life-threatening flash flooding, according to the weather service.\n\nThe significant flooding could result in some roads being washed away and flooded. \"Similar past events have led to flash flood related fatalities from people attempting to drive across flooded roads,\" the weather service said. \"Do not drive across flooded areas - the current may sweep your vehicle off the road, or the weight of your vehicle may collapse the road.\"\n\nThe weather service also advised people living along rivers and creeks to make preparations for possible moderate to major flooding developing later this week. The risk of major flooding is highest for the following rivers: Lumber River, Little Pee Dee River, Black Creek, Northeast Cape Fear River and Waccamaw River.\n\nINTERACTIVE MAP: Enter your address to see hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed nearby\n\nStorm surge of 2 to 4 feet is possible from Cape Fear southward, which includes Brunswick County. The threat of surge will increase, especially around high tide Wednesday through Friday morning. This could impact roads prone to coastal flooding and areas where the shoreline is weak from previous storms.\n\nOn Monday, the weather service also said there is a marginal risk of tornadoes, primarily across portions of northeastSouth Carolina, beginning tonight. Forecasters are assessing how this threat could change through Tuesday and beyond.\n\nRough surf, including dangerous rip currents, and hazardous marine conditions are expected through much of the week.\n\nHurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30. Even if this system won't pose a threat to the NC coast, it's never too early to be prepared.\n\nGET READY: Are you prepared for a hurricane? {"uri": "8260771540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:39:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:39:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:38:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/153155/hurricane-debby-hits-florida", "title": "Hurricane Debby Hits Florida", "body": "Hurricane Debby made landfall near the town of Steinhatchee, Florida, at 7 a.m. Eastern Time on August 5, 2024, as a Category 1 storm. As it moves northeast, the storm is forecast to stall over the U.S. Southeast and deliver torrential rainfall.\n\nThis GeoColor image was captured by the ABI (Advanced Baseline Imager) on the GOES-16 (Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite-16) at 3 a.m. Eastern Time, four hours before Debby made landfall. The satellite is operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), which includes the National Weather Service (NWS). NASA helps develop and launch the GOES series of satellites, which observe Earth from about 22,000 miles (36,000 kilometers) above the equator.\n\nDebby developed into a tropical storm on August 3 in the Gulf of Mexico, becoming the fourth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season. Bands of intense rainfall soon began to lash western Florida, dumping over a foot (30 centimeters) of rain near Sarasota between August 3 and 4.\n\nBy August 5, Debby had grown into a Category 1 storm with sustained winds of around 80 miles (130 kilometers) per hour at the time of landfall. As of 11 a.m. Eastern Time that day, over 207,000 homes were without power, according to PowerOutage.us. NWS forecasts called for the storm to bring 10 to 20 inches of rain and \"life-threatening\" storm surge of up to 10 feet to parts of the Big Bend region, where Florida's panhandle curves to meet the peninsula.\n\n\"There's a lot of warm water and low vertical wind shear in the Gulf of Mexico right now, which are two key ingredients for storm intensification,\" said Patrick Duran, a hurricane expert at NASA's Short-Term Prediction Research and Transition (SPoRT) project, based at Marshall Space Flight Center. Vertical wind shear is the difference in the speed and direction of lower-level and upper-level winds. High shear rips the tops off of developing hurricanes and weakens them, while low shear allows storms to build.\n\nNASA's SPoRT team focuses on improving weather forecasts using satellite data from NASA and NOAA. Duran uses the ABI instrument on GOES satellites in his work to look at fine-scale structures in clouds and find the center of a storm's circulation. ABI's infrared bands are used during the day and night to look at the depth of a storm's convection and how it is developing.\n\nDebby hit the same stretch of sparsely populated land as Idalia, which came ashore as a Category 3 hurricane in August 2023. Though Debby is weaker than Idalia, its slower pace means it could unleash \"potentially historic\" rain across the Southeast, according to the NWS. Forecasts indicate that from August 5 to 10, parts of southeast Georgia, coastal South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina could see 10 to 20 inches of rain, with up to 30 inches possible in some {"uri": "2024-08-445119109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:29:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:29:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:19:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/2024-08-05-tropical-storm-debby-tracker-rain-flooding-records", "title": "Tropical Storm Debby Tracker: Rain Maps And More", "body": "Tropical Storm Debby is hammering parts of the Southeast with torrential rainfall, but it still has much more ahead in what could be a historic rain event with major flooding from Florida into Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. We have maps to track Debby's heavy rain now, its forecast, perspective on state rainfall records and comparisons to recent tropical rain events in the region.\n\nFor the full details, including a complete forecast, please read our latest forecast article here.\n\nParts of western and northern Florida have already picked up over 12 inches of rain.\n\nReminder: impacts are expected well beyond the edge of the cone, which is a forecast only of the center of Debby.\n\nThe map in the post below shows areas where river flooding is forecast in the U.S., including from Debby, according to NOAA. River locations forecast to be pushed into minor (orange), moderate (red) and major (purple) flood stage are shown as colored dots, as of the time of the post.\n\nFor now, any statewide rainfall records seem most in jeopardy in South Carolina. Below are some all-time records for the state, according to NOAA meteorologist David Roth, NOAA/NCEI and weather historian Christopher Burt.\n\nSouth Carolina\n\n- 24-hour rainfall record: 14.80 inches at Myrtle Beach in Sept. 1999, during Hurricane Floyd.\n\n- All-time record rainfall from a tropical cyclone: 23.63 inches at Loris in Sept. 2018 during Hurricane Florence.\n\n- Lingered over/near the Carolinas for almost three days after landfall.\n\n- Peak rainfall total: 35.93 inches near Elizabethtown, N.C. and 23.763 inches at Loris, S.C, both state records for any tropical system.\n\n- An estimated 10 trillion gallons of rain fell on the Carolinas.\n\n- Total estimated damage: $29.8 billion (2024 dollars); Damage in N.C. alone was more than they experienced in Hurricanes Matthew (2016) and Floyd (1999), combined, according to NOAA.\n\nMatthew (Oct. 2016)\n\n- Hugged the coast from Georgia to the Carolinas for about 36 hours as a hurricane before it moved offshore.\n\n- Peak rainfall total: 18.95 inches near Evergreen, North Carolina. Areas from coastal Georgia to southeast Virginia picked up over 12 inches of rain with rainfall rates as high as 7 inches per hour.\n\n- 100,000 homes, businesses, structures flooded in eastern North Carolina after historic river flooding that lasted for weeks.\n\n- Total estimated U.S. damage: $13 billion (2024 dollars), according to OAA.\n\nUpper Low Taps \"Joaquin\" (Oct. 2015)\n\n- Weird, swirling upper-level low over the Southeast U.S. tapped moisture from distant Hurricane Joaquin and pumped it into South Carolina for several days\n\n- Peak rainfall total: 27.15 inches at Mt. Pleasant; several other locations picked up over 20 inches of rain during the event\n\n- Multiple dam breaches occurred in Columbia, South Carolina; Stretches of Interstate 95 were closed for weeks (FOX Carolina) - Debby is drifting slowly through Southeast Georgia toward the Atlantic Ocean. It's expected to slip off the coast and over the water allowing for some strengthening. Heavy rains continue to pummel the coast and Midlands with heavier rainfall ahead.\n\nDebby continues to move slowly as it tracks northeast across Southeast Georgia, nearing Savannah Tuesday morning. The forecast track continues to have the system exiting the southeast Georgia coast on Tuesday afternoon then drifting northeastward along or near the South Carolina coast through Thursday. If it spends a good amount of time over the warm Atlantic waters, the storm could intensify some before moving back onshore by Thursday afternoon, likely as strong tropical storm.\n\nThe storm's slow movement is the biggest issue. This allows 2-3 more days of onshore winds for the Georgia and South Carolina coasts, leading to widespread flooding from ocean waters alone. The onshore flow also pulls in a constant fetch of ample moisture off the Atlantic Ocean, leading to persistent, torrential rain over the same areas for several days.\n\nThe coast is under high alert for the potential for historic flooding. There is a possibility Debby could produce as much rain as some areas saw from 1000 year rain in 2015. Monday brought a record breaking 4.7'' of rain to North Charleston and that was the \"light\" rain day. There doesn't look to be any relief in sight until late Friday.\n\nThe Midlands is also looking at a prolific event, but it's a steep decline in rainfall from east to west. It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.\n\nForecasters warned heavy amounts of rain from Debby could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.\n\nMore than 300,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000, according to PowerOutage.us and Georgia Electric Membership Corp.\n\nAirports, including in North Texas were also affected. {"uri": "8260836770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:03:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:03:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:56:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/08/06/mil-osi-usa-hurricane-debby-hits-florida/", "title": "MIL-OSI USA: Hurricane Debby Hits Florida", "body": "Hurricane Debby made landfall near the town of Steinhatchee, Florida, at 7 a.m. Eastern Time on August 5, 2024, as a Category 1 storm. As it moves northeast, the storm is forecast to stall over the U.S. Southeast and deliver torrential rainfall.\n\nThis GeoColor image was captured by the ABI (Advanced Baseline Imager) on the GOES-16 (Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite-16) at 3 a.m. Eastern Time, four hours before Debby made landfall. The satellite is operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), which includes the National Weather Service (NWS). NASA helps develop and launch the GOES series of satellites, which observe Earth from about 22,000 miles (36,000 kilometers) above the equator.\n\nDebby developed into a tropical storm on August 3 in the Gulf of Mexico, becoming the fourth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season. Bands of intense rainfall soon began to lash western Florida, dumping over a foot (30 centimeters) of rain near Sarasota between August 3 and 4.\n\nBy August 5, Debby had grown into a Category 1 storm with sustained winds of around 80 miles (130 kilometers) per hour at the time of landfall. As of 11 a.m. Eastern Time that day, over 207,000 homes were without power, according to PowerOutage.us. NWS forecasts called for the storm to bring 10 to 20 inches of rain and \"life-threatening\" storm surge of up to 10 feet to parts of the Big Bend region, where Florida's panhandle curves to meet the peninsula.\n\n\"There's a lot of warm water and low vertical wind shear in the Gulf of Mexico right now, which are two key ingredients for storm intensification,\" said Patrick Duran, a hurricane expert at NASA's Short-Term Prediction Research and Transition (SPoRT) project, based at Marshall Space Flight Center. Vertical wind shear is the difference in the speed and direction of lower-level and upper-level winds. High shear rips the tops off of developing hurricanes and weakens them, while low shear allows storms to build.\n\nNASA's SPoRT team focuses on improving weather forecasts using satellite data from NASA and NOAA. Duran uses the ABI instrument on GOES satellites in his work to look at fine-scale structures in clouds and find the center of a storm's circulation. ABI's infrared bands are used during the day and night to look at the depth of a storm's convection and how it is developing.\n\nDebby hit the same stretch of sparsely populated land as Idalia, which came ashore as a Category 3 hurricane in August 2023. Though Debby is weaker than Idalia, its slower pace means it could unleash \"potentially historic\" rain across the Southeast, according to the NWS. Forecasts indicate that from August 5 to 10, parts of southeast Georgia, coastal South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina could see 10 to 20 inches of rain, with up to 30 inches possible in some places.\n\nNASA Earth Observatory image by Lauren Dauphin, using GOES 16 imagery courtesy of NOAA and the National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service (NESDIS). After crashing into Florida, the storm has been downgraded to a tropical storm.\n\nDebby is expected to creep across the state and into southern Georgia over the next day.\n\nAs it swept up the west coast and reached land, the winds and rain knocked out power for hundreds of thousands of Floridians. DeSantis' office said over 300,000 have already had their electricity restored. However, as of Monday morning, nearly 150,000 people are still without power.\n\nSee Also: Debby brings more than strong storms: 25 cocaine bricks wash ashore FL Keys\n\nCrews with the Florida Department of Transportation have surveyed approximately 4,500 miles of state roads to gauge their condition and see if they are still passable. Several public transit lines also shut down operations on Monday because of flooding, while others focused their efforts on evacuating people to local emergency shelters.\n\nTallahassee International Airport and Gainesville Regional Airport were both closed because of the weather and were set to reopen when safe, the governor's office stated. It predicted the latter airport would open at 11:30 p.m.\n\nAdditionally, the State Assistance Information Line is available for Floridians needing help either before or after the storm by calling 800-342-3557.\n\nAhead of the Debby, DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 61 counties. {"uri": "8260712805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:35:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:35:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.dcvelocity.com/articles/61543-hurricane-debby-threatens-catastrophic-flooding-across-southeast", "title": "Hurricane Debby threatens \"catastrophic flooding\" across Southeast", "body": "Ports of Jacksonville, Savannah, and Charleston see threat of supply chain disruptions.\n\nFlooding could disrupt supply chains across the Southeast U.S. this week, as Hurricane Debby sweeps slowly over the region state with drenching rain after making landfall this morning in northern Florida's Big Bend.\n\nThe region's major cargo airports will likely duck those impacts, but there is a high risk of flooding at the ports of Jacksonville, Savannah, and Charleston, as well as eight intermodal hubs around Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina, according to a video press conference from supply chain risk management firm Everstream Analytics.\n\nAlthough it has lower wind speeds forecast than past storms like Hurricane Beryl just last month, the hurricane could do most of its damage through extended, soaking rainfall.\n\nThat's because the Category 1 storm will lose strength after moving off the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico, leaving its remnants to drift very slowly and \"basically stall out\" across the Southeast region over the next five days, Everstream Chief Meteorologist Jon Davis said. The result will be a \"major flooding event\" due to the long duration of impacts, leading to \"extremely high rainfall totals\" that could cause significant supply chain disruptions, he said.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) had similar warnings, saying \"Potentially historic heavy rainfall, associated with Hurricane Debby, across southeast Georgia and South Carolina through Friday morning will likely result in areas of catastrophic flooding.\"\n\nSpecific commercial disruption could strike industries including aerospace & defense, life sciences, manufacturing, oil & gas, and high-tech, according to an analysis by Resilinc. Those potential impacts could involve nearly 17,000 sites at risk, which perform activities like manufacturing, warehousing, distribution, fabrication, and testing.\n\nIn response, the emergency response nonprofit American Logistics Aid Network (ALAN) is urging residents of the Southeast to heed emergency management officials' warnings about everything from safely evacuating to sheltering in place- and asking members of the logistics community to be ready to help. \"In addition to high winds and a significant storm surge, Hurricane Debby has the potential to bring huge amounts of rain and significant flooding to many parts of Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas. That has us especially concerned, because flood waters are often the deadliest and most underestimated effect of a hurricane,\" Kathy Fulton, ALAN's executive director, said in a release.\n\nThe event also highlights the increasing need to improve supply chain resiliency, according to Moody's. In an analysis, the firm noted that following Hurricane Beryl, which was the earliest Category 5 hurricane on record in the North Atlantic Basin, Hurricane Debby is the second U.S. hurricane landfall of 2024, which is forecast to be an active hurricane season. \"With the increasing frequency and severity of hurricanes, the resilience of supply chains faces unprecedented challenges,\" John Donigian, Supplier Risk Management Strategy, Moody's, said in a statement. \"Proactive supply chain planning, backed by advanced risk data and analytics, is essential. For instance, by analyzing real-time data on hurricane paths and intensities, businesses can pre-emptively reroute shipments, secure alternative suppliers, and adjust inventory levels to mitigate potential disruptions.\"", "source": {"uri": "dcvelocity.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DC Velocity"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Sadly, at least 4 people have died as a result from this system so far.\n\nAs of the 5 PM advisory on Monday, Tropical Storm Debby has maximum sustained wind of 50 mph and is crawling northeast at 6 mph.\n\nDebby is expected to bring nearly 2 feet of rain to parts of Georgia and South Carolina. This will bring widespread flash flooding that will be catastrophic and life threatening.\n\nLocal Impacts From Debby:\n\nThere will be a sharp rain total gradient across the area. As of Monday afternoon, rain totals span from 1\" in the mountains to nearly 10\" in Chesterfield county. IF the storm stalls a bit more westward, the rain totals will shift west as well. This means higher totals for more of our area. IF the storm stalls a bit more eastward, it is possible our rain chances will be lower.\n\nTiming: We will see bands roll into our area on Tuesday, but not for everyone. The main timeline is late Wednesday through Saturday. Thursday and Friday will be our highest impact days.\n\nThreats: Flooding is the main threat. Gusty winds are also possible. The tornado threat will be low, but not zero. Downed trees and power outages are possible.\n\nRain Totals:\n\nNow - Wednesday: 0-0.50\" north of I-85. 1-3\" in Chesterfield county. Anson and Richmond could also see upwards of 2\".\n\nWednesday - Saturday:\n\n- Mountains: 0.5\"-2\"\n\n- Foothills: 1-3\"\n\n- Charlotte: 2-5\"\n\n- Southeast of Charlotte: 5-10\"\n\nWind: We could {"uri": "2024-08-445320027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "06:52:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T06:52:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T06:47:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://wgntv.com/weather/weather-blog/debby-produces-torrential-rainfall-in-excess-of-one-foot-across-parts-of-florida/", "title": "Debby produces torrential rainfall in excess of one foot across parts of Florida...", "body": "Goes-16 satellite presentation of Tropical Storm Debby late Monday evening\n\nExtremely intense, very compact storm capable of devastating winds, rains, waves, and storm surges\n\nCATASTROPHIC FLOOD SITUATION COMING TOGETHER OVER THE SOUTHEAST IN THE DAYS AHEAD\n\nBy Tom Skilling (Via Facebook)\n\nThe RAINFALL SITUATION unfolding in the Southeast-centered from a swath of northern Florida north into Georgia and the Carolinas -- is most concerning. The storm will batter the coastal areas of these states with wind, waves, and a storm surge. But, it's the flooding that may prove devastating.\n\nThere is no more prolific rainfall-generating system in nature than a tropical cyclone -- i.e. a hurricane or tropical storm. The rate of rainfall is SO extreme, it overwhelms the ability of soils to absorb or rivers to move water out of affected areas fast enough to prevent flooding. Here the latest National Hurricane Center (NHC) public advisory on Debby: https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/.../MIATCPAT4+shtml/051749.shtml?\n\nTHE METEOROLOGICAL SET-UP BACKSTOPPING THE DEVELOPING EXTREME RAINFALL SITUATION\n\nEstimated Rainfall totals over the coming days\n\nHere's one model (the RRFS high resolution, convection-allowing ensemble model which is to become operational in the months to come and is being run in parallel for testing with other NWS models) estimate of rainfall over just the coming 60 hours. Heavy rainfall is to persist beyond that period as the storm's forward motion slows. \"Ensemble\" model forecasts average across a whole series of forecast solutions rather than relying on a single forecast and therefore attempt to reconcile variations between individual forecasts. Research has shown the ensemble approach to forecasting leads to more accurate predictions.\n\nWith jet stream winds, which might otherwise whisk tropical storm Debby across the Southeast, displaced far to the north, placing the storm in a region of light upper steering winds, a scenario develops in which Debby slows to a crawl in the coming days. This is to take place with the storm over the warm, energy-rich waters of the western Atlantic which are also the source of a prolific source of moisture.\n\nCheck out the Monday morning Environment Canada 500 mb analysis I'm posting which shows steering winds surrounding Debby at the 18,000 ft level of 5 to 10 mph. As a result, forecast models all but stall the system over the region producing local 20'' rainfalls-if not more.\n\nPrecipitable water-that's the atmospheric moisture available in a column of air extending past 30,000 ft into the atmosphere to any precipitation-generating system-is off the charts HIGH-Monday morning approaching 3''. The towering cumulonimbus clouds which populate and, indeed, serve as the core of tropical storms, sweep this moisture into concentrated downpours that produce rainfalls many times the precipitable water values.\n\nOur most humid weather system here in Chicago produced precipitable water values topping 2'' -- what's available to Debby surpasses that. Yet 16.91'' of rain fell on the Greater Chicago area -- a statewide record -- in the historic flooding of July, 1996. That was a single 24 hour period! Imagine what days of rainfall from a stall system may end up producing in the eastern Carolinas!\n\nTHE BENCHMARK FLOOD SITUATION IN SOUTH CAROLINA\n\nHere's a summary from South Carolina's most severe flood episode from the South Carolina State Climatology office:\n\n\"1908 - Flood: The flood of August 26-30, 1908, was the most extensive flood of record; all major rivers in the state rose from 9 to 22 feet above flood stage. A low pressure center formed in the Gulf of Mexico and moved northeastward across South Carolina causing unprecedented statewide flooding. There was heavy damage to crops and property along the rivers.\"\n\nState residents were also confronted by monumental flooding in 1928 and when Hurricane Hugo swept ashore in Sept 1989.\n\nA MORE explained.\n\nIt's too early to predict exact storm totals from Debby but Massachusetts could get soaked by 2-3 inches of rainfall over two days.\n\n\"High-end totals up to 5-7'' cannot be ruled out {"uri": "2024-08-445522417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:00:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:00:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.newsobserver.com/news/weather-news/article290761894.html", "title": "Debby's heavy rains will likely soak ground in NC. What that means for power outages.", "body": "Heavy rains expected this week from what's now Tropical Storm Debby likely will saturate the ground in much of North Carolina, leaving some trees and even power poles vulnerable to being uprooted by gusty winds.\n\nToppled trees and poles can mean downed power lines that cause spotty to widespread outages.\n\nWhat is soil saturation?\n\nNormally, soil has voids where it can take in water, easily absorbing average amounts of rainfall. Saturated soil occurs during periods of heavy or extended rainfall when rainwater fills all the voids, leaving no more spaces.\n\nSaturated soil doesn't hold together as well as unsaturated soil, becoming muddy and pliable.\n\nTree roots, which create friction with unsaturated soil as a tree rocks in the wind, are more likely to slip and slide through saturated soil, reducing the tree's stability and increasing the chance it will uproot and fall in high winds.\n\nHow much rain does it take to saturate the ground?\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says it takes 2 to 2.5 inches of rain to saturate the soil to a depth of about 8 inches.\n\nIn his blog on Monday, Assistant State Climatologist Corey Davis said that after the second-driest June on record for the state overall, North Carolina saw the 11th-wettest July since record-keeping began in 1895. Preliminary totals show a statewide average rainfall of 8.29 inches for the month, Davis said, more than 3 inches above the average from 1991 to 2020.\n\nWhile every county in the state was in some level of drought on July 9, by July 30, when the most recent drought map was published, half the state showed no drought at all and the other half showed abnormally dry with just a few counties in moderate drought.\n\nIn areas where the ground is parched -- or saturated -- meteorologists say, heavy rains tend to run off, causing flash flooding.\n\nHow much rain is coming?\n\nDebby is a slow-moving storm carrying a lot of moisture, and meteorologists say it could drop record-setting amounts of rainfall in southeast Georgia and coastal South Carolina.\n\nAs it comes into North Carolina, Debby is expected to bring:\n\n\u25aa 12 to 16 inches of rain in the extreme southeastern corner of the state;\n\n\u25aa 8 to 12 inches of rain in the area reaching horizontally from Anson County to Pamlico County;\n\n\u25aa 6 to 8 inches in a crescent from Union County to Hatteras Island, including Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill;\n\n\u25aa 4 to 6 inches in a crescent from Charlotte to the northern Outer Banks;\n\nThe National Hurricane Center forecasts as of Monday showed wind speeds associated with Debby of just 5 mph to 20 mph as the storm moves through the southeast before dissipating or moving out to sea.\n\nBasil Camu, a master arborist with Leaf & Limb of Raleigh, said Monday he doesn't expect widespread loss of trees as a result of Debby because the wind speeds will be relatively low. He said some trees are likely to fall along creeks and rivers, however, because of flooding from heaving rains eroding the soil around the roots.\n\nTrees that are diseased or have been damaged, such as having some of their roots bulldozed for a house addition, he said, also could be vulnerable.\n\nOtherwise, he said, in much of North Carolina, \"Our trees and flowers and grasses are still feeling a little dry, so the rain will actually be a good thing for our plants.\"\n\nIs Duke Energy worried?\n\nDuke Energy, the largest electric utility in North Carolina, is bracing for the impacts of Tropical Storm Debby.\n\nLogan Stewart, communications manager for Duke Energy in Charlotte, said Monday the company's meteorologists were saying it's too early to know what effects the storm will have.\n\nWhere heavy rain and flooding do bring down trees onto power lines, she said, it complicates the process of restoring power.\n\nCustomers sometimes get impatient, she said, because it can take takes two crews to restore power after a tree falls: one to cut and remove the tree safely and a second to repair damaged lines.\n\nWith a storm like Debby, Stewart said, \"We may see a lot of scattered outages, individual pockets with one, two, three, four or five customers out. But there will be a lot of them. And we physically send line workers to every single outage. We can't just flip a switch.\"\n\nDuke has sent 350 crew members from the Midwest to help with power outages in Florida, Stewart said, and some of those line workers can come to North Carolina to help out if needed.\n\nMeanwhile, she said, customers should make plans to relocate if the power goes out if they have household members who need electricity to survive.", "source": {"uri": Some strengthening is forecast Wednesday and Thursday as Debby drifts offshore, before it moves inland Thursday over South Carolina.\n\n\"Hunker down,\" Van Johnson, the mayor of Savannah, Georgia, {"uri": "2024-08-446186771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:26:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:26:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:22:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/weather/2024/08/06/debby-set-to-drench-east-coast-2-feet-of-rain-in-forecast/74686643007/", "title": "Debby isn't done: 2 feet of rain and a drenched East Coast in forecast", "body": "Parts of the west coast of Florida were left with flooded streets after Debby dumped more than 10 inches of rain in some spots.\n\nDebby, now downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm, will continue to dump colossal amounts of rainfall across the Southeast and much of the East Coast over the next few days, likely leading to catastrophic flooding in some areas.\n\nDebby drenched northern Florida as it churned toward Georgia and the Carolinas, threatening a week of torrential downpours and flooding. The storm has already been blamed for at least five deaths.\n\nAccording to AccuWeather, the heaviest swath of rainfall totals of 18-24 inches is expected to occur across far southeast Georgia and southern South Carolina, including around the cities of Savannah and Charleston.\n\nThe rain will slowly make its way up the East Coast during the week and will likely reach New England by the weekend, where the NWS in Boston issued this warning Tuesday: \"Rises on rivers as well as flash flooding are possible, but an uncertain storm track casts uncertainty on where the heaviest rain falls.\"\n\nHow much rain will fall? By the time Debby dissipates this upcoming weekend, the storm will have dropped upwards of 50 trillion gallons of rain on the eastern United States from Florida to Maine, according to meteorologist Ryan Maue.\n\nMaue says that makes Debby the wettest landfalling hurricane ever, even topping such powerhouse rainmakers as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. That storm dumped more than 27 trillion gallons of rain over Texas, according to the Texas Division of Emergency Management.\n\nWhy is there so much rain?\n\nDebby is a \"slow-moving storm,\" said Brian Haines, the meteorologist-in-charge at the National Weather Service in Charleston, South Carolina. This allows the storm to dump huge amounts of rainfall.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said, \"The cyclone is situated in an area of weak steering currents.\" That means the storm has stalled, University of Miami meteorologist Brian McNoldy said on his blog, which \"will be responsible for a very significant flooding threat this week.\"\n\nWhile some tropical cyclones increase in forward speed as they move north, Debby is crawling along at only 6 mph, as of Tuesday afternoon, the NHC said.\n\nDrought buster in the Mid-Atlantic?\n\nFor some in the Mid-Atlantic, Debby's rain will be \"good news,\" according to the Capital Weather Gang blog, as \"drought is extreme over a large portion of Washington's western suburbs as well as into adjacent parts of West Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania.\"\n\n\"It's often the case that tropical rainstorms end summer droughts and Debby offers that possibility,\" according to the Capital Weather Gang.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com",
